questions.text: A 66-year-old woman with hypertension comes to the physician because of crampy, dull abdominal pain and weight loss for 1 month. The pain is located in the epigastric region and typically occurs within the first hour after eating. She has had a 7-kg (15.4-lb) weight loss in the past month. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Physical examination shows a scaphoid abdomen and diffuse tenderness to palpation. Laboratory studies including carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9), carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and lipase concentrations are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Malignant mass at the head of the pancreas
Embolus in the superior mesenteric artery
Focal wall thickening in the colon
Decreased motility of gastric smooth muscle

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Slow progressive narrowing of the celiac artery secondary to atherosclerosis can lead to chronic mesenteric ischemia, which manifests with the signs and symptoms seen in this patient. She likely also has atherosclerotic narrowing of the SMA or IMA. If only one main artery is affected, collateral connections will typically compensate for the reduced flow and the patient will often be asymptomatic.
Image Description:

The gastrointestinal tract is supplied by the three anterior branches of the abdominal aorta.
- Celiac artery: artery of the foregut (lower esophagus, stomach, proximal duodenum, liver, gall bladder, pancreas)
- Superior mesenteric artery: artery of the midgut (distal duodenum, jejunum, ileum, cecum, ascending colon, proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon)
- Inferior mesenteric artery: artery of the hindgut (distal third of the transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, rectum, anal canal proximal to the pectinate line)

B) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic cancer causes abdominal pain and weight loss, as in this patient, and smoking is also a known risk factor. However, this patient lacks other common signs of pancreatic cancer, including nausea and vomiting. Pancreatic cancer involving the head typically also causes obstructive jaundice, which is not present. Lastly, laboratory values typically elevated in patients with pancreatic cancer, including CA 19-9, CEA, and lipase, are all normal. This combination of findings makes pancreatic cancer an unlikely cause of this patient's symptoms.
Image Description:

Tumors of the pancreatic head may obstruct the extrahepatic bile ducts and pancreatic duct. Bile duct obstruction results in Courvoisier sign (painless jaundice plus an enlarged, nontender gallbladder on palpation), pale stools, dark urine, and pruritus. Pancreatic duct obstruction results in exocrine pancreatic insufficiency and steatorrhea. The obstruction-related dilation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct demonstrates as the double-duct sign on radiology.

C) INCORRECT:

Gastric outlet obstruction results from narrowing of the gastric pylorus and presents with postprandial pain and weight loss, as seen in this patient. However, she lacks the vomiting that is seen in nearly all patients with gastric outlet obstruction, making this diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Arterial thromboembolism to the superior mesenteric artery causes acute mesenteric ischemia. This presents with sudden, severe, periumbilical pain, often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The pain is classically disproportionate to abdominal examination findings. Instead, this patient presents with chronic mesenteric ischemia and has a gradual onset of symptoms associated with post-prandial pain and weight loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Focal wall thickening in the colon can represent a colonic mass or infectious colitis. Although both could potentially cause weight loss, these diagnoses do not explain the postprandial pain seen in this patient. Furthermore, she lacks other typical symptoms for colonic mass or infectious colitis, such as hematochezia.

F) INCORRECT:

Decreased motility of gastric smooth muscle causes gastroparesis, a condition that presents with postprandial pain and in severe cases, weight loss. However, this patient lacks other typical symptoms of gastroparesis, including nausea and vomiting. She also lacks risk factors such as diabetes or a history of upper GI surgery, making this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: A 66-year-old woman with multiple atherosclerotic risk factors (hypertension, smoking) who presents with chronic postprandial pain, food avoidance, and unintentional weight loss, should raise concern for chronic mesenteric ischemia.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of crushing substernal chest pain at rest for the past 2 hours. She is diaphoretic. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 115/65 mm Hg. An ECG shows ST elevation in I, aVL, and V2–V4. Coronary angiography shows an 80% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery. Which of the following is the most likely initial step in the pathogenesis of this patient's coronary condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intimal smooth muscle cells migration is mediated by macrophages producing platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and fibroblast growth factor (FGF). However, intimal smooth muscle cell migration is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Intimal monocyte infiltration is one of the first steps in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis. After adhesion to the endothelium, the monocytes emigrate through the endothelium into the intima. As the endothelium is physiologically impermeable to monocytes, monocyte infiltration is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Platelet activation releases a variety of inflammatory mediators and thereby recruits inflammatory cells towards the site of the atherosclerotic lesion. However, platelets are only activated after adhesion to the endothelium of affected vessels. Therefore, platelet activation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) oxidation releases cholesterol, which is then ingested by macrophages, inducing foam cell formation. However, attraction and activation of macrophages happen before the formation of foam cells. Therefore, LDL oxidation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

E) CORRECT:

The development of atherosclerosis begins with an external factor (e.g., hypertension, smoking, advanced glycation end-products) damaging the endothelium, which increases adhesiveness and leads to local inflammation and invasion of smooth muscle cells into the tunica intima. Inflammatory cytokines attract macrophages, which then form foam cells by taking up cholesterol from oxidized low-density lipids. These foam cells accumulate to form fatty streaks (early atherosclerotic lesions). Finally, collagen production by lipid-laden macrophages and smooth muscle cells form these fatty streaks into a fibrous plaque.

F) INCORRECT:

Intimal foam cell accumulation is a consequence of macrophages infiltrating the intima and ingesting cholesterol from oxidized LDL. These foam cells accumulate and form fatty streaks. However, intimal foam cell accumulation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Fibrous plaque formation is mediated by macrophages, lymphocytes, and smooth muscle cells. Together with deposited extracellular matrix (e.g., collagen), these cell types form the fibrous plaque in atherosclerosis. However, fibrous plaque formation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (acute, crushing substernal chest pain, diaphoresis) and ECG changes indicate a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome (ACS). The angiography showing a stenosis of the left anterior descending artery confirms the diagnosis. ACS is caused primarily by atherosclerosis.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 1-day history of headache, blurry vision, and confusion. His wife also says that he has not urinated in the past 24 hours. Despite appropriate measures, the patient dies shortly after admission. A photomicrograph of a section of the kidney obtained at autopsy is shown. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the findings indicated by the arrow?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A mycotic aneurysm, which is caused by infection of the arterial wall, affects large and medium-sized vessels such as the aorta, intracranial arteries, and arteries of the lower limbs. Small arteries, such as the renal arterioles, are typically not affected.

B) CORRECT:

This patient with acute-onset oliguria, headache, blurry vision, and confusion most likely had a hypertensive emergency. Acute increases in blood pressure can lead to hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis. Chronic hypertension can result in hyaline arteriolosclerosis, which is characterized by deposition of homogeneous eosinophilic material in the vessel wall and sclerotic changes (e.g., glomerular shrinkage, periglomerular fibrosis) in the renal parenchyma.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic hyperglycemia due to diabetes mellitus would result in thickening of the renal arteriolar walls and narrowing of the lumen as seen in this patient. However, the thickening is due to hyaline arteriolosclerosis, resulting in deposition of homogeneous eosinophilic material in the vessel wall, and not hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis. Also, the glomeruli in patients with chronic hyperglycemia would show mesangial expansion with nodular (Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions) or diffuse hyaline deposits.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain; high magnification)

A cross-section of a glomerulus can be seen (dashed outline), featuring a thickened glomerular basement membrane and containing abundant pink, hyaline depositions of PAS-positive material (Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules or nodular glomerulosclerosis; examples indicated by yellow overlay). Various tubules and vessels surround the glomerulus. An arteriole with distinct hyaline deposits is located above the glomerulus (hyaline arteriolosclerosis; blue overlay).

Nodular glomerulosclerosis combined with hyaline arteriolosclerosis is a typical feature seen in diabetic glomerulopathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Necrotizing vasculitis of the renal arterioles, which is seen in vasculitides such as microscopic polyangiitis, Wegener granulomatosis, and Churg-Strauss syndrome, can result in thickening of the renal arteriolar walls. This thickening would be due to fibrinoid necrosis, resulting in eosinophilic deposits in the vessel wall with inflammatory cells (e.g., neutrophils) in the adventitia, but it would not be due to hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis. Also, the glomeruli in patients with any of these conditions would show features of RPGN (e.g., glomerular crescents),.
Image Description:

Microscopic image of arteriole in the lung tissues (H&E stain)

The wall of the arteriole exhibits annular deposition of amorphous and proteinaceous material, and inflammatory infiltrates.

These are the typical features of fibrinoid necrosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque can result in acute renal injury due to occlusion of the renal artery by a thrombus or due to occlusion of the renal arterioles by cholesterol crystal embolization. However, in both of these conditions, the kidney would show features of coagulative necrosis in the renal glomeruli (e.g., karyolysis, highly eosinophilic cytoplasm) and tubules (e.g., sloughed debris in the lumen) as a result of infarction.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a renal biopsy sample (H&E stain)

The cells of the tubules and glomeruli show clumped and highly eosinophilic cytoplasm. The nuclei of these cells are either absent or palely staining. There is debris in some tubular lumens and thrombi are visible in the capillaries on the lower right. The main outlines of the tubules and glomeruli are still intact.
questions.hint: The renal biopsy shows an arteriole with an “onion-skin” appearance as a result of smooth muscle hyperplasia and basement membrane duplication. This is characteristic of hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia is brought to the emergency department by his wife for difficulty breathing after choking on food at dinner. He is unconscious and pulseless on arrival. Despite appropriate life-saving measures, he dies. Examination of the heart shows a necrotic, pale yellow plaque in the left circumflex artery. Similar lesions are most likely to be found in which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the subclavian arteries can occur through thromboses, compression by surrounding structures (e.g., Pancoast tumor), and certain forms of vasculitis (e.g., Takayasu arteritis). While atherosclerosis can also affect these arteries, they are a less common site for the development of plaques.

B) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the superficial temporal artery is classically caused by giant cell arteritis. However, this artery is less commonly affected by atherosclerosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the renal arteries can occur through fibromuscular dysplasia and certain forms of vasculitis (e.g., polyarteritis nodosa). While atherosclerosis can affect the renal arteries, they are a less common site for the development of plaques.

D) CORRECT:

The abdominal aorta is the most common site for the development of atherosclerotic plaques, followed by the coronary, popliteal, and internal carotid arteries. Turbulent, high-pressure flow in these vessels places chronic strain on the endothelium. The abdominal aorta lacks vasa vasorum below the level of the renal arteries and is therefore particularly susceptible to endothelial injury.
Image Description:

In healthy aterial blood vessels (upper image), turbulent flows occur in aortic ramifications and bifurcations, exposing the endothelium here to increased stress as a result. For this reason, these locations are affected more often and more severely by atherosclerotic changes and plaque formation (lower image), especially in the presence of risk factors.

E) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the thoracic aorta can occur through aneurysm and/or vessel dissection. While atherosclerosis can affect this region, the thoracic aorta is not the most common area for the development of atherosclerotic plaques.

F) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the internal carotid arteries can occur through vessel dissection or stenosis. While these arteries can be affected by atherosclerosis, they are less commonly affected than other regions.

G) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the pulmonary arteries can occur due to emboli (e.g., thrombotic, air, or fat) and certain forms of vasculitis (e.g., Takayasu arteritis). However, these arteries are less commonly affected by atherosclerosis.
questions.hint: The coronary lesion described on this patient's autopsy is an atherosclerotic plaque. These plaques typically appear in vessels with high levels of endothelial strain.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man with coronary artery disease and hypertension is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 90 minutes after the acute onset of substernal chest pain and dyspnea. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 52 years. Shortly after arriving at the hospital, he loses consciousness and is pulseless. Despite attempts at cardiopulmonary resuscitation, he dies. Examination of the heart at autopsy shows complete occlusion of the left anterior descending artery with a red thrombus overlying a necrotic plaque. Which of the following pathophysiologic mechanisms is most likely responsible for this patient's coronary occlusion?

choices.text: Influx of lipids into the endothelium
Migration of macrophages to the tunica intima

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Stasis of blood flow is part of the tripartite pathophysiology of deep venous thrombosis. The other two contributing factors are endothelial damage and relative hypercoagulability (Virchow triad). However, the hemodynamics of the coronary arteries is characterized by high-speed flow, even in the case of mural thrombus. Endothelial damage and relative hypercoagulability play a more prominent role than stasis in the pathophysiology of atheromas and this patient's myocardial infarction.

B) INCORRECT:

The influx of lipids into the endothelium is responsible for atheroma formation. Because lipids are not normally found in the endothelium, their presence sets off a potent immune response, which is what ultimately causes the nascent atheroma to develop and enlarge. However, the presence of lipids does not play a role in the acute rupture of the atheroma.

C) CORRECT:

The secretion of matrix metalloproteinases is thought to be responsible for breaking down the fibrous cap of an atheroma. Matrix metalloproteinases, which are secreted by inflammatory cells in the atheroma (e.g., macrophages), weaken the fibrous cap by breaking down the extracellular matrix. Subsequently, minor stress can rupture the fibrous cap and expose the atheroma's highly thrombogenic lipid core. It is this event that then causes the acute, total obstruction of the vessel and subsequent myocardial infarction.

D) INCORRECT:

Platelet-derived growth factor induces smooth muscle hyperplasia and fibroblast growth in the atheroma. Although this is considered a crucial pathophysiologic mechanism in the growth of an atheroma, platelet-derived growth factor plays no direct role in acute plaque rupture.

E) INCORRECT:

Migration of macrophages to the tunica intima is responsible for the formation of the atheroma, but it is not responsible for rupture of the atheroma.
questions.hint: The cause of death in this patient is an acute myocardial infarction due to acute plaque rupture and thrombosis, as evidenced by the autopsy finding of coronary occlusion by a red thrombus (composed of platelets and fibrin). Plaque rupture occurs when the protective cap covering the plaque loses its integrity and thrombotic material causes vessel obstruction.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the physician for a 4-month history of recurrent episodes of retrosternal chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, and nausea. The episodes usually start after physical activity and subside within minutes of resting. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He is 176 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (209 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. His blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg. Coronary angiography shows an atherosclerotic lesion with stenosis of the left anterior descending artery. Compared to normal healthy coronary arteries, increased levels of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) are found in this lesion. Which of the following is the most likely effect of this factor?

choices.text: Increased expression of vascular cell-adhesion molecules
Accumulation of foam cells to form fatty streaks
Calcification of the atherosclerotic plaque core
Intimal migration of smooth muscle cells
Ingestion of cholesterol by mature monocytes
Invasion of T-cells through the disrupted endothelium
Adherence of platelets to injured subendothelium
Inflammatory cytokine release from the endothelium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased expression of vascular cell-adhesion molecules is an essential process in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis. In response to inflammation, endothelial cells increase the expression of ICAM-1 and begin expressing other cell-adhesion molecules such as vascular cell adhesion molecule 1 (VCAM-1). The increased expression of VCAM-1 leads to adhesion and subsequent migration of leukocytes. However, PDGF does not increase the expression of vascular cell-adhesion molecules.

B) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of foam cells in the intima, forming fatty streaks together with intracellular and extracellular lipid deposits, is one of the first steps in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis. PDGF release does not mediate the accumulation of foam cells to form fatty streaks.

C) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the atherosclerotic plaque core is one of the final steps in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis. As the atherosclerotic plaque grows, it causes stenosis of the vessel lumen, which subsequently reduces blood flow and results in ischemia (manifesting as angina pectoris in this patient). However, PDGF does not mediate the calcification of the atherosclerotic plaque core.

D) CORRECT:

Platelet-derived growth factor is a growth factor that binds to tyrosine kinase receptors and stimulates the transition of cells from the G1 phase to the S phase. PDGF is released at atherosclerotic lesion sites by platelets and macrophages and stimulates proliferation and migration of smooth muscles cells in the tunica intima, an important step in atherosclerosis that occurs in response to endothelial injury. PDGF also mediates the differentiation of fibroblasts into myofibroblasts, which is necessary for fibrous cap formation.

E) INCORRECT:

During atherosclerosis, monocytes migrate into the intima to mature into macrophages, which ingest cholesterol from oxidized LDL and then turn into foam cells. Although macrophages can secrete PDGF, ingestion of cholesterol by mature monocytes is not mediated by PDGF.

F) INCORRECT:

Invasion of T-cells through the disrupted endothelium is the result of increased permeability of the damaged endothelium during atherosclerosis. Damaged endothelial cells express an increased number of cell-adhesion molecules, which mediate the adherence of leukocytes. However, PDGF does not mediate the invasion of T-cells through the disrupted endothelium.

G) INCORRECT:

Platelet adherence to damaged subendothelium in atherosclerosis is triggered by the increased permeability of endothelium due to the deleterious effects of long-standing hypertension or diabetes. PDGF does not mediate platelet adherence.

H) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory cytokine release from the endothelium (e.g., IL-1 and TNF-α) enhances the expression of cell-adhesion molecules on endothelial cells and promotes the migration of leukocytes in atherosclerosis. PDGF does not mediate cytokine release from the endothelium.
questions.hint: This patient's stenosis on angiography restricts coronary blood flow and is most likely the cause of his recurrent episodes of angina pectoris (retrosternal chest pain, dyspnea, dizziness, and nausea).

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with systolic heart failure secondary to amyloidosis undergoes heart transplantation. The donor heart is obtained from a 17-year-old boy who died in a motor vehicle collision. Examination of the donor heart during the procedure shows a flat, yellow-white discoloration with an irregular border on the luminal surface of the aorta. A biopsy of this lesion is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Lipoprotein-laden macrophages (foam cells) within the intimal layer of vessels are seen in the early stage of atherogenesis, which corresponds to the fatty streak phase. Fatty streaks appear macroscopically as flat yellow discolorations with irregular borders on the luminal surfaces of blood vessels, including the aorta. Starting in early adulthood, fatty streaks may be visible with the naked eye.

B) INCORRECT:

Proteoglycan accumulation is seen in the fibrous plaque phase of atherogenesis. Fibrous plaques are the result of the accumulation and proliferation of lipid-filled smooth muscle cells and macrophages, which induce deposition of extracellular matrix (e.g., proteoglycans and elastin). They are seen in patients with a long history of atherosclerosis, which is unlikely in a 17-year-old donor.

C) INCORRECT:

Apoptosis of smooth muscle cells is seen in the late stages of fatty streak formation. As the fatty streak progresses, smooth muscle and macrophages accumulate in the intimal layer of vessels; apoptosis of the smooth muscle cells within the deep layer of the fatty streak can occur. These changes result in microvesicles that undergo calcification and contribute to the formation of atherosclerotic plaques. On macroscopic examination, atherosclerotic plaques are visible as raised pale yellow lesions that impede and obstruct arteries, rather than the flat lesions seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Necrotic cell debris can be seen in advanced atherosclerosis. Advanced atherosclerotic lesions usually expand beyond the intimal layer of vessels and contain a necrotic lipid-rich core with calcifications. Macroscopically, advanced atherosclerosis appears as calcified, raised, pale, yellow lesions with a necrotic lipid-rich core and cholesterol crystallization, rather than the flat yellow lesions seen here. Moreover, advanced atherosclerosis would not be expected in a 17-year-old donor.

E) INCORRECT:

Dystrophic calcification occurs in advanced atherosclerotic lesions that expand beyond the intimal layer of vessels. These lesions are most commonly seen in patients with a long history of atherosclerosis. Dystrophic calcifications appear as raised pale yellow lesions with a necrotic lipid-rich core, rather than the flat yellow lesions seen here. Moreover, advanced atherosclerosis would not be expected in a 17-year-old donor.

F) INCORRECT:

Collagen deposition is seen in the fibrous plaque phase of atherogenesis. Fibrous plaques are the result of the accumulation and proliferation of lipid-filled smooth muscle cells and deposition of extracellular matrix (e.g., collagen and elastin). They are seen in patients with a long history of atherosclerosis, which is unlikely in a 17-year-old donor.
questions.hint: The morphology (flat, yellow-white intimal discoloration) and location (luminal surface) of the lesion corresponds with the fatty streak stage of atherogenesis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He recently moved to the area. He feels well. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus, and his paternal uncle had prostate cancer at the age of 73 years. The patient does not smoke cigarettes. He drinks three glasses of wine weekly. He works as a scriptwriter for a film production company and runs marathons to raise money for charity organizations in his free time. He has been monogamous with his wife for 15 years. He is 185 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Early detection and treatment of hyperlipidemia is crucial to prevent ASCVD events like stroke or myocardial infarction. The guidelines for hyperlipidemia screening differ slightly among various expert groups. The current consensus is to screen all individuals aged 20–75 years using a fasting or nonfasting serum lipid profile test every 4–6 years in patients without additional ASCVD risk factors and at more frequent intervals in those with additional ASCVD risk factors.

See “Screening recommendations for men by age” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia and gonorrhea are the most common causes of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Although PID is most often asymptomatic, it can result in severe complications, including infertility and ectopic pregnancy. Therefore, both the USPSTF and CDC recommend annual screening with a nucleic acid amplification test for chlamydia and gonorrhea in sexually active women < 25 years and women ≥ 25 years with certain risk factors (e.g., new or multiple sex partners, a sex partner with an STI). The CDC also recommends annual screening for both sexually active HIV-positive men and men who have sex with men because of the higher incidence of gonorrhea and chlamydia infections in these populations. Routine chlamydia and gonorrhea screening is not currently recommended for sexually active, HIV-negative men in monogamous, heterosexual relationships, such as this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The AHA and other expert groups do recommend screening for a certain disease in this patient's age group.

D) INCORRECT:

The guidelines for prostate cancer screening differ slightly among various expert groups but the USPSTF recommends screening men aged 55–69 years with a life expectancy of at least 10 years after informing the patient of the benefits as well as risks of prostate cancer screening (e.g., relatively high false-positive rate, additional unnecessary procedures), i.e., by employing a shared decision-making strategy. Prostate cancer screening is most commonly performed using a serum prostate-specific antigen test every 2 years. Screening can be initiated earlier at 40 years for patients with a first-degree relative who developed early-onset prostate cancer (i.e., before 65 years). This 42-year-old patient with a second-degree relative who developed prostate cancer at the age of 73 years does not require prostate cancer screening at this visit.

E) INCORRECT:

There is insufficient evidence to recommend routine screening for osteoporosis in men, but screening can be considered in men with strong risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., long-term corticosteroid use; androgen deprivation therapy for prostate cancer) and in men ≥ 70 years of age. In this 42-year old man without such risk factors, screening for osteoporosis is not recommended.
questions.hint: Screening for this disorder is recommended by the American Heart Association and various other expert groups for the primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular diseases (ASCVD).

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He feels well. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. Routine colonoscopy screening from 2 months ago showed diverticulosis. His maternal aunt died from myocardial infarction at the age of 63 years. He does not smoke cigarettes and drinks three to four 12-oz beers weekly. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. His blood pressure is 124/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
15.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
6000/mm3



Hemoglobin A1C

6.2%


Serum



Total cholesterol
185 mg/dL


HDL cholesterol
45 mg/dL


LDL cholesterol
122 mg/dL


Triglycerides
140 mg/dL


The patient's estimated 10-year risk of cardiovascular disease is 9.1%. In addition to counseling on lifestyle modifications, which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Low-dose aspirin therapy is indicated for patients who have ASCVD (for secondary prevention) and can be considered for patients aged 40–59 years with a 10-year ASCVD risk ≥ 10% and a low risk of bleeding (for primary prevention). At this time, a different drug should be prescribed for this patient who does not yet have ASCVD but has an estimated 10-year ASCVD risk of 9.1%.

B) CORRECT:

The indications for statins for primary prevention of ASCVD vary slightly between guidelines. The American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA) recommend initiating statin therapy (e.g., atorvastatin, rosuvastatin) in patients 40–75 years of age with T2DM regardless of their 10-year ASCVD risk. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) considers it beneficial to initiate statin therapy in patients with ≥ 1 modifiable traditional ASCVD risk factor (e.g., diabetes) and a 10-year ASCVD risk of ≥ 7.5%. According to both guidelines, there is a benefit to initiating statin therapy in this patient. See the “Indications for statins for primary ASCVD prevention” table.

For reference, see the 2019 ACC/AHA guidelines https://www.ahajournals.org/doi/10.1161/CIR.0000000000000678 and the USPSTF recommendations https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2795521.

C) INCORRECT:

Dapagliflozin is an oral antidiabetic agent that can be added to the drug regimen of a patient with T2DM if monotherapy with metformin has not achieved the HbA1C target of < 7%. This patient, however, has good glycemic control (HbA1C of 6.2%) on metformin alone and, thus, does not require a second antidiabetic drug.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients 40–75 years of age with T2DM and a 10-year ASCVD risk ≥ 7.5% should be prescribed a specific drug for health maintenance.

E) INCORRECT:

Niacin is used in the treatment of hypertriglyceridemia, which this patient does not have. In addition, niacin should be avoided in patients with diabetes since it can negatively impact glycemic control. A different drug should be prescribed to this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe is a second-line lipid-lowering agent that can be used for additional ASCVD risk reduction in patients who do not achieve target LDL reduction with the maximally tolerated dose of first-line therapy. This patient's LDL cholesterol is within the reference range.
questions.hint: This patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and an intermediate atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk (7.5%–20%) requires intervention for primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD).

choices.text: No change in medication is indicated at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metformin is the initial drug of choice in all patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Diagnostic criteria for diabetes mellitus include a random blood glucose level ≥ 200 mg/dL in patients with symptoms of hyperglycemia or two abnormal hyperglycemia tests (e.g., fasting plasma glucose) in those without symptoms. Although this patient has a glucose concentration of 126 mg/dL, he may not have fasted for 8 hours prior to this visit. Moreover, two abnormal test results are required for diagnosis in an asymptomatic individual.

B) INCORRECT:

Non-vitamin K antagonist oral anticoagulants (NOACs), such as apixaban, are preferred to warfarin for a variety of conditions because it is not necessary to monitor coagulation parameters (e.g., INR) during therapy. However, the safety and efficacy of NOACs in patients with mechanical valves have not been established, and their use is not recommended.

C) CORRECT:

Patients aged 40–75 years with a high risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular diseases (ASCVD) should be started on high-intensity statin therapy (e.g., with atorvastatin) regardless of their LDL levels, for primary prevention of ASCVD. Other indications for high-intensity statin therapy include LDL ≥ 190 mg/dL and/or a history of clinical ASCVD.

Statin therapy does not play a role in the progression of aortic stenosis, and this patient's recent history of aortic valve replacement is not an indication for treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient is on appropriate therapy for his mechanical aortic valve. However, because of his high risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, a medication change is indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is often used to treat volume overload in patients with congestive heart failure (CHF). Although this patient has 1+ peripheral edema, he has no other signs of CHF (e.g., symptoms of pulmonary congestion). His peripheral edema is likely an adverse effect of amlodipine, which causes precapillary vasodilation, increasing hydrostatic pressure. ACE inhibitors can be used to attenuate edema due to calcium channel blockers by causing postcapillary vasodilation, which normalizes hydrostatic pressure.
questions.hint: Because of his age, gender, cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., hypertension, smoking history), and borderline high LDL cholesterol levels, this patient has a high 10-year ASCVD risk with a calculated score of 20.3%.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and documented coronary artery disease returns to discuss the results of a fasting lipid panel. He is feeling well. His current medications include aspirin 81 mg once daily, simvastatin 40 mg once daily, atenolol 50 mg once daily, and lisinopril 20 mg once daily.
Laboratory testing reveals lipid values of 203 mg/dL for total cholesterol, 125 mg/dL for LDL cholesterol, 40 mg/dL for HDL cholesterol, and 190 mg/dL for triglycerides.
In addition to reinforcing recommended therapeutic lifestyle changes, which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Continue simvastatin 40 mg once daily and add ezetimibe 10 mg once daily
Increase the dose of simvastatin to 80 mg once daily
Replace simvastatin with atorvastatin 80 mg once daily
Continue simvastatin 40 mg once daily and add gemfibrozil 600 mg twice daily
Replace simvastatin with pravastatin 40 mg once daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

According to the 2018 ACC/AHA cholesterol guidelines, ezetimibe can reasonably be added to the regimens of high-risk patients who are already on maximally tolerated statins with LDL-cholesterol levels ≥70 mg/dL. The addition of ezetimibe to a statin can help lower LDL-cholesterol by an additional 13% to 20%. This patient is not on maximally tolerated statin therapy yet, so the addition of ezetimibe would not be indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Increasing the dose of simvastatin to 80 mg daily is not appropriate. First, the LDL-lowering effect of this dose of simvastatin is only modestly higher than the 40-mg dose, putting it in the category of moderate-intensity statins. Second, although this dose of simvastatin was investigated in clinical trials, subsequent data showed an unacceptably high rate of myopathy with this dose. Therefore, no patients should be started on an 80-mg dose of simvastatin. It might be reasonable to continue simvastatin 80 mg daily in patients who have been taking this dose for a long time and who are tolerating it. However, even in these patients, clinicians should consider switching to a different and more potent statin.

C) CORRECT:

Current cholesterol treatment guidelines from the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA) recommend a high-intensity statin (atorvastatin 40–80 mg or rosuvastatin 20–40 mg daily) as first-line therapy in adults ≤ 75 years of age who have clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD). The evidence supports high-intensity statin therapy for this group to achieve a ≥ 50% reduction in LDL-cholesterol levels. This patient is currently taking a moderate-intensity statin (simvastatin 40 mg daily), which is expected to achieve only a 30% to 49% reduction in LDL-cholesterol levels; he should therefore be switched to a high-intensity statin.

Key learning point: The first-line lipid management approach for patients ≤75 years of age with established coronary artery disease is treatment with a high-intensity statin.

D) INCORRECT:

The fibrate gemfibrozil is most useful for lowering a patient's triglyceride level and for raising the HDL-cholesterol level, not for lowering the LDL-cholesterol level.

E) INCORRECT:

Pravastatin 40 mg is unlikely to yield any additional LDL-lowering benefit or risk reduction beyond that of simvastatin 40 mg.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man asks about his cardiovascular risk after one of his coworkers had urgent coronary bypass surgery. The patient has no family history of coronary disease. He does not smoke, and he has no history of diabetes mellitus. He has a BMI of 24.3 and a blood pressure of 118/65 mm Hg.
Recent laboratory studies revealed a total cholesterol level of 185 mg/dL, an LDL-cholesterol level of 116 mg/dL, and an HDL-cholesterol level of 41 mg/dL.
Which one of the following approaches is most appropriate for assessing this patient’s cardiovascular risk?

choices.text: Assess lipoproteins, apolipoproteins, and particle size and density
Calculate a global risk score for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lipid subfraction levels (beyond total, LDL, and HDL cholesterol) correlate statistically with CHD risk; added to traditional risk factors, they may reclassify a small proportion of intermediate-risk patients into higher- or lower-risk categories. However, testing for these nontraditional risk factors has not been shown to improve clinical outcomes.

B) INCORRECT:

C-reactive protein levels correlate statistically with CHD risk; added to traditional risk factors, they may reclassify a small proportion of intermediate-risk patients into higher- or lower-risk categories. However, testing for these nontraditional risk factors has not been shown to improve clinical outcomes.

C) CORRECT:

Major independent risk factors for heart disease include cigarette smoking, elevated blood pressure, diabetes mellitus, advanced age, elevated serum total-cholesterol and LDL-cholesterol levels, and a low serum HDL-cholesterol level.

Several calculators are available to determine a patient’s 10-year cardiovascular risk on the basis of these risk factors. For example, the American Heart Association (AHA) and American College of Cardiology (ACC) have published a risk calculator based on the 2013 ACC/AHA pooled cohort equation that includes race in addition to the aforementioned risk factors and provides an estimated 10-year risk for myocardial infarction or stroke. More recently, researchers developed the U.S. Multi-Ethnic Study for Atherosclerosis (MESA) risk score to predict a patient’s 10-year coronary heart disease (CHD) risk. This score includes all of the risk factors in the AHA/ACC calculator plus a coronary artery calcium score and family history of heart attack.

With both of these calculators, the 10-year risks for this patient are below the threshold for initiating statin therapy.

Key learning point: In addition to measuring BMI, blood pressure, glycated hemoglobin level, and cholesterol levels, the best way to determine cardiovascular risk in an asymptomatic 50-year-old man is to calculate a global risk score for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Exercise treadmill testing has no clearly defined role in the routine risk stratification of asymptomatic, low-risk people.

E) INCORRECT:

Electrocardiography has no clearly defined role in the routine risk stratification of asymptomatic, low-risk people.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old woman with a history of hypothyroidism and peripheral arterial disease returns for evaluation of her most recent lipid profile. She is physically active and has no current symptoms at rest or with exertion. She takes aspirin, amlodipine, levothyroxine, and calcium supplements. Her blood pressure is well controlled, with the latest measurement being 128/77 mm Hg. After visiting a nutritionist last year, she went on a low-cholesterol diet.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
240
—


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
135
—


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
35
—


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
350
—


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
2.2
0.5–4.7


Which one of the following therapies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Niacin is not a first-line therapy for the treatment of hyperlipidemia or hypertriglyceridemia and is known to cause flushing and impaired glucose tolerance.

B) INCORRECT:

Cholestyramine, a bile-acid sequestrant used for LDL reduction, is not a first-line agent. It often causes gastrointestinal side effects (e.g., bloating, loose stools) and impedes absorption of fat-soluble vitamins and certain medications (e.g., digoxin, warfarin, beta-blockers).

C) INCORRECT:

Gemfibrozil is used primarily to reduce elevated triglyceride levels. It is second-line therapy in a patient with multiple CHD risk factors.

Medications that specifically lower triglyceride levels are appropriate for patients whose triglyceride level exceeds 500 mg/dL; at this level, the primary goal of treatment is to prevent pancreatitis related to hypertriglyceridemia. Therapy can consist of a fibrate or fish-oil supplements.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism can be associated with an elevated LDL-cholesterol level. Triiodothyronine is not indicated for managing hyperlipidemia in a patient with well-controlled hypothyroidism.

E) CORRECT:

Few data are available on the use of statins for primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) in individuals over 75 years of age because few people in this age group were included in the randomized, controlled trials of statins. The evidence base for using statins for primary prevention in this age group is therefore limited, but the consensus is that such use is likely beneficial, especially in patients who are already taking and tolerating these drugs.

Although still limited, a larger amount of data supports the use of statin therapy for secondary prevention in individuals over 75 years of age who have clinical ASCVD. In this physically active patient, the presence of peripheral arterial disease is clinical evidence of ASCVD, so a moderate- or high-intensity statin should be considered for secondary prevention. The decision to start a statin should be made after assessment of the potential for ASCVD risk reduction, side effects, medication interactions, patient frailty, and patient preferences. This is in contrast to the guidelines for individuals ≤75 years of age, which state that all patients with established ASCVD should receive statin therapy that is of high intensity.

Unlike statins, other cholesterol-lowering medications, such as gemfibrozil and niacin, provide little benefit in reducing the risk for all-cause or cardiac mortality. Thus, statins are the first-line treatment.

Key learning point: Patients with established peripheral arterial disease should receive a statin for secondary prevention, even if they are >75 years of age.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman is seen for follow-up of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Six months ago, she was started on chlorthalidone when her blood pressures were consistently elevated, and she was started on atorvastatin 20 mg daily when a fasting lipid panel revealed a total cholesterol level of 260 mg/dL (reference range, 125–200), an LDL-cholesterol level of 179 mg/dL (< 130), and an HDL-cholesterol level of 42 mg/dL (≥ 46). Before starting the chlorthalidone and atorvastatin, a comprehensive metabolic panel (including liver enzymes and fasting blood glucose) was normal.
The patient has a family history of coronary artery disease. She does not consume alcohol, and she quit smoking several years ago. She feels well and takes no other prescription or over-the-counter medications.
Her current laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range



Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
74
0–35



Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
83
0–35


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
88
30–120


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.9
0.3–1.0


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
110
< 130


Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There is no need to replace atorvastatin with pravastatin. Asymptomatic elevations in alanine aminotransferase or aspartate aminotransferase, up to three times the upper limit of normal, are seen in less than 1% to 3% of patients taking statins. These changes in liver enzyme levels are not a reason to discontinue or change the statin. Thus, the patient's current medications should be continued.

B) INCORRECT:

Replacing chlorthalidone with hydrochlorothiazide is not necessary, because chlorthalidone does not typically cause elevated liver enzymes.

C) INCORRECT:

There is no need to replace atorvastatin with fenofibrate (which is not a first-line agent for lowering LDL cholesterol).

D) INCORRECT:

There is no need to halve the dose of atorvastatin. Asymptomatic elevations in alanine aminotransferase or aspartate aminotransferase, up to three times the upper limit of normal, are seen in less than 1% to 3% of patients taking statins. These changes in liver enzyme levels are not a reason to discontinue or change the statin. Thus, the patient's current medications should be continued.

E) CORRECT:

Asymptomatic elevations in alanine aminotransferase or aspartate aminotransferase, up to three times the upper limit of normal, are seen in less than 1% to 3% of patients taking statins. Thus, the patient's current medications should be continued. Marked aminotransferase elevations (more than five times the upper limit of normal) with or without fever, myalgias, and jaundice indicate true hypersensitivity.

Data from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s Adverse Event Reporting System for 2000 to 2009 found statin-associated serious liver injury to be extremely rare (≤ 2 cases per one million patient-years). In addition, the National Lipid Association Statin Safety Task Force found no benefit of routinely monitoring liver function tests. Given these recommendations, prescribing guidelines and drug safety labels recommend assessing liver enzymes before initiating statin therapy — but no periodic monitoring thereafter, unless clinically indicated.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for mild, asymptomatic elevations of serum aminotransferases (to three times the upper limit of normal) following initiation of a statin is to continue the statin.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man with HIV infection has a CD4 count of 425 cells/mm3 (reference range, 400–1600) and an undetectable HIV viral load while taking tenofovir-emtricitabine and ritonavir-boosted darunavir. (He is taking this regimen because of previous HIV drug resistance.) He has hypertension, for which he takes lisinopril 20 mg daily, and he smokes half a pack of cigarettes each day. His father had coronary artery disease, requiring percutaneous intervention at age 60.
A fasting lipid panel, obtained at the patient’s last visit 3 months ago, yielded these results:



Patient value


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
256


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
165


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
33


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
149


At that prior visit, the patient received lifestyle-modification counseling. His current BMI is 27, and his blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. The fasting lipid panel is repeated and is unchanged. His estimated 10-year risk of a cardiovascular event is 14%.
Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clinicians should be aware that there are significant drug-drug interactions between certain statins and HIV medications, in particular ritonavir-boosted protease inhibitors (PIs) and cobicistat (a pharmacologic booster). These antiretrovirals inhibit the metabolism of medications that are cleared via certain cytochrome P-450 enzymes (mainly CYP3A4), greatly increasing statin exposure and potentially leading to dose-dependent toxicity, such as myositis. Because of these drug-drug interactions, PIs and cobicistat should not be coadministered with statins that are highly metabolized by CYP3A4 (such as lovastatin and simvastatin).

B) INCORRECT:

Niacin is not an appropriate first-line choice for managing hypercholesterolemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty-acid supplementation can be considered for severe hypertriglyceridemia but is not an appropriate first-line choice for managing hypercholesterolemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Gemfibrozil is not an appropriate first-line choice for managing hypercholesterolemia.

E) CORRECT:

Lipid abnormalities are very common in patients with HIV infection, due both to HIV itself and to some antiretroviral medications. Among patients who take protease inhibitors (PIs), the prevalence of dyslipidemia is as high as 60%, depending on the PI.

Management of hypercholesterolemia in patients with HIV infection should be based on the same cholesterol treatment guidelines used for patients without HIV infection. However, HIV infection is considered a chronic inflammatory condition that increases the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD); in the current (2018) guidelines for management of cholesterol, such risk-enhancing factors can be considered in addition to traditional ASCVD risk factors to help guide the decision to start statin therapy. Other risk enhancers include family history of premature ASCVD, chronic kidney disease, history of preeclampsia, metabolic syndrome, and high-risk race/ethnicity (such as South Asian ancestry).

For patients such as this one, without diabetes, who are aged 40 to 75 and whose LDL-cholesterol level is between 70 and 189 mg/dL, the guidelines recommend calculating the 10-year ASCVD risk. This patient falls in the intermediate risk category (≥7.5% to <20% 10-year risk) where guidelines recommend discussing the risk with the patient, considering risk enhancers, and typically initiating therapy with a moderate-intensity statin. In this patient who has the risk enhancer of HIV infection, a moderate-intensity statin should be recommended.

Clinicians should be aware that there are significant drug-drug interactions between certain statins and HIV medications, in particular ritonavir-boosted PIs and cobicistat (a pharmacologic booster). These antiretrovirals inhibit the metabolism of medications that are cleared via certain cytochrome P-450 enzymes (mainly CYP3A4), greatly increasing statin exposure and potentially leading to dose-dependent toxicity, such as myositis. Because of these drug-drug interactions, PIs and cobicistat should not be coadministered with statins that are highly metabolized by CYP3A4 (such as lovastatin and simvastatin). Safer options are pitavastatin, low-dose rosuvastatin, and low-dose atorvastatin.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first-line pharmacologic treatment of hypercholesterolemia in a patient with HIV infection who is taking protease inhibitors is a statin (although treatment with simvastatin and lovastatin should be avoided).

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man with no clinically significant medical history has gained 9 kg during the past few years. His meals come mostly from restaurants. He takes no medications, does not smoke, and drinks approximately two beers on weekends. His father underwent placement of a coronary artery stent at age 60.
On examination, the patient’s blood pressure is 127/75 mm Hg, his heart rate is 70 beats per minute, and his BMI is 30. His waist circumference is 104 cm.
Fasting laboratory studies yield the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Glucose (mg/dL)
91
70–100


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
245
—


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
200
—


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
170
—


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
35
≥40


His estimated 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is 3.6%.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The 2018 ACC/AHA consensus guideline on the management of blood cholesterol identified four "statin benefit" groups for whom atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk reduction clearly outweighs the risk for adverse effects:

• Individuals with clinical ASCVD
• Individuals with an LDL-cholesterol level ≥190 mg/dL
• Individuals with diabetes mellitus who are age 40 to 75 years regardless of their estimated 10-year ASCVD risk
• Individuals without clinical ASCVD or diabetes mellitus who are 40 to 75 years of age with an LDL-cholesterol level of 70 to 189 mg/dL and an estimated 10-year risk for ASCVD of ≥7.5%.

Although this patient has an LDL-cholesterol level of 170 mg/dL, his estimated 10-year risk for ASCVD is only 3.6% (based on the ACC/AHA cardiovascular risk calculator: http://static.heart.org/riskcalc/app/index.html#!/baseline-risk). For individuals with a 10-year ASCVD risk <5%, the guidelines recommend beginning with lifestyle modification, with the option of eventually considering drug therapy (a statin) if the patient does not achieve his target.

All patients with an elevated LDL-cholesterol level should undergo lifestyle modification, which includes weight loss, aerobic exercise, and improvement in dietary habits.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management of hyperlipidemia in a 40-year-old man with a sedentary lifestyle, poor dietary habits, an LDL-cholesterol level of 170 mg/dL, and a 3.6% 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is lifestyle modification.

B) INCORRECT:

For individuals with a 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk <5%, the guidelines recommend beginning with lifestyle modification, with the option of eventually considering drug therapy (a statin) if the patient does not achieve his target.

C) INCORRECT:

Current guidelines suggest that nonstatin therapies do not provide acceptable atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk reduction benefits compared to their potential for adverse effects in the routine prevention of ASCVD.

D) INCORRECT:

There is no robust evidence that basing management on homocysteine or lipoprotein(a) levels improves clinical outcomes.

E) INCORRECT:

There is no robust evidence that basing management on homocysteine or lipoprotein(a) levels improves clinical outcomes.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man with no significant medical history presents to discuss his cholesterol levels. He is married, has no children, does not use tobacco, drinks approximately seven alcoholic beverages per week, and reports no use of illicit drugs. He takes leisurely walks with his wife on weekends but is otherwise sedentary. Both of his parents have type 2 diabetes.
On physical examination, his height is 178 cm, his weight is 77 kg, and his BMI is 24.4. His seated blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 76 beats per minute. His waist circumference is 88 cm. The remainder of his examination is unremarkable.
His fasting laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value


Glucose (mg/dL)
90


Glycated hemoglobin (%)
5.5


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
187


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
130


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
31


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
130


His lifetime risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is estimated at 36%.
Which one of the following recommendations is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients without diabetes who are younger than 40 years of age, routine initiation of a statin is typically recommended only if the LDL-cholesterol level exceeds 190 mg/dL — or if the LDL-cholesterol level exceeds 160 mg/dL in a patient who has a family history of premature atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. This patient’s LDL-cholesterol level (130 mg/dL) is lower than this threshold, and therefore a statin (such as atorvastatin) is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has an isolated low level of HDL cholesterol in the absence of other lipid abnormalities or heart disease. Although low HDL cholesterol is a coronary risk factor, the clinical benefit of treatment to raise isolated low HDL-cholesterol levels is controversial. Drugs such as fenofibrate and niacin raise HDL-cholesterol levels, but they should not be prescribed to otherwise low-risk patients with isolated low HDL-cholesterol levels. Even in patients with known coronary disease, clinical trials of adding a fibrate or niacin to statin therapy have not consistently shown improved outcomes.

C) CORRECT:

The main focus of lipid-modifying therapy is to reduce the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD). In patients without diabetes who are younger than 40 years of age, routine initiation of a statin is typically recommended only if the LDL-cholesterol level exceeds 190 mg/dL — or if the LDL-cholesterol level exceeds 160 mg/dL in a patient who has a family history of premature ASCVD.

The ASCVD risk calculator can be used to calculate lifetime ASCVD risk in patients as young as 20 years of age, but it will only calculate a 10-year risk in those who are 40 years of age or older. A patient’s 10-year risk of ASCVD is recommended as a starting point for the discussion about cardiovascular risk reduction in individuals who are older than 40 years of age and can help guide clinicians toward a recommendation regarding initiation of statin therapy in this age group. In patients who are 20 to 39 years of age, only the estimated lifetime risk can be calculated. This risk estimate can be used to encourage lifestyle interventions but does not directly factor into the decision regarding initiation of statin therapy, which, in this age group, is based more on absolute LDL-cholesterol numbers and family history.

Exercise raises the HDL-cholesterol level and should be recommended for sedentary people even apart from its effect on serum lipids.

Key learning point: The first-line intervention for a young man with an isolated low level of HDL cholesterol in the absence of known heart disease is an increase in physical activity.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has an isolated low level of HDL cholesterol in the absence of other lipid abnormalities or heart disease. Although low HDL cholesterol is a coronary risk factor, the clinical benefit of treatment to raise isolated low HDL-cholesterol levels is controversial. Drugs such as fenofibrate and niacin raise HDL-cholesterol levels, but they should not be prescribed to otherwise low-risk patients with isolated low HDL-cholesterol levels. Even in patients with known coronary disease, clinical trials of adding a fibrate or niacin to statin therapy have not consistently shown improved outcomes.

E) INCORRECT:

Moderate alcohol intake raises HDL-cholesterol levels; this effect may partly explain why moderate alcohol intake is associated with lower coronary risk. Excessive alcohol intake is defined as >14 drinks per week in men and >7 drinks per week in women. Because this patient’s weekly alcohol intake is not considered to be excessive, reducing intake is not a therapeutic priority.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman with hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and mild asthma reports a one-year history of pain in her calves when she walks more than a few blocks. She was recently started on cilostazol, and she reports that her walking distance until onset of pain has improved somewhat.
She takes aspirin 81 mg daily, hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily, cilostazol 100 mg twice daily, and pravastatin 20 mg daily. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for 40 years but does not drink alcohol. Both of her parents had hypertension but not coronary artery disease.
Her current blood pressure is 129/75 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 62 beats per minute. Her pedal pulses are not palpable. Femoral pulses are normal.
Laboratory testing identifies a creatinine concentration of 0.9 mg/dL (reference range, 0.6–1.1) and the following lipid levels: LDL cholesterol, 137 mg/dL; HDL cholesterol, 39 mg/dL; and total cholesterol, 215 mg/dL.
Results of liver function tests are normal. The ankle-brachial pressure index is 0.7 in both lower extremities.
In addition to encouraging walking and smoking cessation, what is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Replace the aspirin 81 mg daily with clopidogrel 75 mg daily
Replace the pravastatin 20 mg daily with atorvastatin 80 mg daily
Start warfarin, with a target international normalized ratio of 2.0
Continue aspirin 81 mg daily, and add clopidogrel 75 mg daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is an appropriate antiplatelet agent for this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Pentoxifylline is of questionable clinical benefit for managing symptomatic claudication in patients with peripheral vascular disease. This patient is already taking cilostazol, which has been shown in clinical trials to improve walking distance in patients with claudication.

C) CORRECT:

Peripheral vascular disease is characterized by claudication (pain with walking), diminished peripheral pulses, and skin changes in the affected extremities (e.g., skin cool to the touch, bluish discoloration of the feet). An ankle-brachial pressure index ≤0.9 supports a diagnosis of peripheral vascular disease.

One goal of care in patients with peripheral vascular diseases is to reduce symptoms. In the case of intermittent claudication, this can be achieved with exercise therapy and pharmacologic therapies such as cilostazol. Of note, none of the answer options in this case would provide symptomatic benefit. A second goal is to reduce the patient’s cardiovascular risk. Guidelines indicate that patients with clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) — including peripheral vascular disease — receive high-intensity statin therapy. High-intensity statin therapy with atorvastatin 40 mg to 80 mg reduces overall ASCVD risk more than low-intensity statin therapy with pravastatin 20 mg.

Key learning point: The dose of atorvastatin that is recommended for a patient with symptomatic peripheral vascular disease is 40 to 80 mg daily.

D) INCORRECT:

Warfarin is not indicated unless a thrombus is present or a thromboembolic event has occurred.

E) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is an appropriate antiplatelet agent for this patient; there is no proven advantage in adding clopidogrel or substituting it for aspirin (unless the patient has a contraindication to aspirin, in which case clopidogrel may be chosen as an alternative antiplatelet agent).

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman with documented coronary disease reports a one-month history of diffuse muscle aches. She also notes an increase in fatigue and an inability to exercise as much as she would like. She has had no fevers, chills, joint swelling, or recent trauma.
Treatment with atorvastatin 40 mg daily, aspirin, and metoprolol was initiated 6 months ago after she was diagnosed with a non-Q-wave myocardial infarction.
Her vital signs are normal, and she has no erythema, rashes, or joint swelling. Her muscle strength is 5 out of 5 in all extremities. Her muscles are mildly tender to palpation.
The results of her liver function tests are within normal limits.
Other laboratory testing yields the following results:

≥46

190
<150

Creatinine (mg/dL)

Creatine kinase (U/liter)
230
40–150


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
2.5
0.5–4.7


25-hydroxyvitamin D (ng/mL)
32

Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Continue atorvastatin at the current dose
Stop atorvastatin, then start niacin when symptoms have resolved
Stop atorvastatin, then start rosuvastatin when symptoms have resolved
Stop atorvastatin, then start ezetimibe when symptoms have resolved
Stop atorvastatin, then remeasure lipid levels in 2 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the symptoms are mild but interfering with activity and quality of life, and the creatine kinase level is ≤5 times the upper limit of normal, a reasonable first step is to lower the dose or switch to another statin, rather than continuing at the current dose.

B) INCORRECT:

The evidence supporting secondary preventive benefit is more robust for statins than for other lipid-lowering drugs; hence, switching to another drug class such as niacin is a less desirable initial approach in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Patients taking statins are at risk for myopathy, which is characterized by myalgias and/or muscle weakness, particularly of the upper limbs or trunk. In a patient who has myalgias, creatine kinase, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels should be checked, because the myalgias may be linked to conditions unrelated to statin use, such as thyroid disease or vitamin D deficiency.

The reasons to continue statin therapy are more compelling in a patient with a recent coronary event (i.e., secondary prevention) than in a patient for whom the statin is prescribed for primary prevention. If the symptoms are mild but interfering with activity and quality of life, and the creatine kinase level is ≤5 times the upper limit of normal, a reasonable first step — informed by anecdotal evidence but not randomized trials — is to lower the dose or switch to another statin. Studies have found that at least half of patients who stop taking a statin because of adverse muscle effects are able to resume taking a statin. The hydrophilic statins (pravastatin and rosuvastatin) can be a good choice for a replacement when patients have myalgias while taking a lipophilic statin.

Key learning point: In a patient with coronary artery disease who is taking a high dose of a statin and has mild myalgias with a mildly increased creatine kinase level, the appropriate treatment is to lower the dose or switch to a different statin.

D) INCORRECT:

The evidence supporting secondary preventive benefit is more robust for statins than for other lipid-lowering drugs; hence, switching to another drug class such as ezetimibe is a less desirable initial approach in this patient. If a rechallenge with a statin is unsuccessful, then either ezetimibe or an inhibitor of proprotein convertase subtilisin-kexin type 9 serine protease (PCSK9) such as evolocumab or alirocumab would be other options, but only after attempting to resume statin therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Because this patient’s indication for statin therapy is compelling, stopping entirely and remeasuring lipids at a future date is suboptimal. However, statins should be stopped at least temporarily if the symptoms are severe, the creatine kinase level is at least 5 times the upper limit of normal, or there is renal impairment.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man with a history of obesity and hypertension presents for routine care. His hypertension is currently being treated with hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily only. He takes no other medications. He leads a sedentary lifestyle, consumes a diet high in saturated fats, does not smoke, and has one glass of wine with dinner 5 to 6 nights per week. He has no family history of premature coronary heart disease.
On physical examination, he is afebrile, with a blood pressure of 128/80 mm Hg, a heart rate of 80 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. His height is 165 cm, his weight is 94 kg, his BMI is 34.5, and his waist circumference is 114 cm. Overall, he appears to be well, with central obesity but no moon facies, striae, dorsocervical fat deposition, or supraclavicular fullness. He does have mild acanthosis nigricans on his neck. The remainder of his physical examination is normal.
Laboratory findings are as follows:

Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in managing this patient’s cholesterol levels?

choices.text: Estimate the patient's 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Current cholesterol-lowering guidelines recommend initiating pharmacologic therapy in adults with clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), diabetes mellitus, an LDL-cholesterol level ≥190 mg/dL, or a ≥7.5% estimated 10-year ASCVD risk. Although this patient has an elevated triglyceride level and low HDL-cholesterol concentration, his glycated hemoglobin level is in the prediabetic rather than the diabetic range, and his estimated 10-year ASCVD risk is only 6.5% (based on the ACC/AHA cardiovascular risk calculator: http://static.heart.org/riskcalc/app/index.html#!/baseline-risk), so pharmacologic therapy is not mandatory at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Current cholesterol-lowering guidelines recommend initiating statin therapy in adults with clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), diabetes mellitus, an LDL-cholesterol level ≥190 mg/dL, or a ≥7.5% estimated 10-year ASCVD risk. Although this patient has an elevated triglyceride level and low HDL-cholesterol concentration, his glycated hemoglobin level is in the prediabetic rather than the diabetic range, and his estimated 10-year ASCVD risk is only 6.5% (based on the ACC/AHA cardiovascular risk calculator: http://static.heart.org/riskcalc/app/index.html#!/baseline-risk), so pharmacologic therapy is not mandatory at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Current cholesterol-lowering guidelines recommend initiating pharmacologic therapy in adults with clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), diabetes mellitus, an LDL-cholesterol level ≥190 mg/dL, or a ≥7.5% estimated 10-year ASCVD risk. Although this patient has an elevated triglyceride level and low HDL-cholesterol concentration, his glycated hemoglobin level is in the prediabetic rather than the diabetic range, and his estimated 10-year ASCVD risk is only 6.5% (based on the ACC/AHA cardiovascular risk calculator: http://static.heart.org/riskcalc/app/index.html#!/baseline-risk), so pharmacologic therapy is not mandatory at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Although observational studies suggest that high intake of dietary fish oil is associated with reduced cardiovascular risk, randomized trials of omega-3 fatty acid supplementation in patients with known coronary disease have yielded mixed results for secondary prevention. The REDUCE-IT trial showed that, compared with placebo, regular use of icosapent ethyl was associated with improved cardiovascular outcomes among patients with high triglyceride levels who had known cardiovascular disease or relevant risk factors and were already taking statin therapy. Our patient, however, does not fit this category.

E) CORRECT:

Current cholesterol-lowering guidelines recommend initiating statin therapy in adults with clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), diabetes mellitus, an LDL-cholesterol level ≥190 mg/dL, or a ≥7.5% estimated 10-year ASCVD risk. Although this patient has an elevated triglyceride level and low HDL-cholesterol concentration, his glycated hemoglobin level is in the prediabetic rather than the diabetic range, and his estimated 10-year ASCVD risk is only 6.5% (based on the ACC/AHA cardiovascular risk calculator: http://static.heart.org/riskcalc/app/index.html#!/baseline-risk), so pharmacologic therapy is not mandatory at this time.

In patients with (or at high risk for) ASCVD, statins appear to lower risk of cardiovascular death more effectively than other lipid-lowering agents such as fibrates (e.g., gemfibrozil or fenofibrate) or niacin. Thus, statins are the treatment of choice for patients with high 10-year ASCVD risk and moderately elevated triglyceride levels. However, in patients with very high triglyceride levels (>500–1000 mg/dL), drugs that target triglycerides more directly (e.g., fibrates) are recommended to prevent pancreatitis. When patients have both a high 10-year ASCVD risk and severely elevated triglyceride levels (e.g., >1000 mg/dL), dual therapy with a statin plus fibrate or niacin may be considered, but risk for adverse effects (including myopathy) rises.

Key learning point: The best way to manage a patient with an elevated triglyceride level and a low HDL-cholesterol level is to base therapy on the patient's estimated 10-year risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man with a history of stage 1 hypertension and obesity presents for follow-up related to his blood pressure and lipid levels. He currently takes no medications. He is 180 cm tall, weighs 107 kg, and has a BMI of 33. His blood pressure is 138/86 mm Hg. His father and one brother had myocardial infarctions at ages 51 and 52, respectively. During the past year, he has tried to adopt a low-fat diet and increase his exercise level, but he has had minimal success.
His fasting morning laboratory findings are as follows:
