The patient’s estimated 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is 9.0% according to the risk calculator of the American College of Cardiology and American Heart Association.
Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has a mild-to-moderate elevation of his triglyceride level; fibrate drugs (e.g., gemfibrozil, fenofibrate) can lower triglyceride levels to a greater degree than statins. However, statin therapy constitutes first-line lipid-lowering therapy in primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Fibrate therapy (primarily to reduce risk of pancreatitis) would be appropriate if the patient’s elevation in triglycerides was severe (e.g., >500 mg/dL).

B) INCORRECT:

Metformin has been shown to slow the rate at which patients with impaired fasting glucose and impaired glucose tolerance progress to meeting formal criteria for diabetes. Metformin is not indicated in a patient with a normal fasting blood-glucose level.

C) CORRECT:

The American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA) have identified four groups of patients for whom the benefits of statin therapy outweigh the risks in terms of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD):

• Patients with clinical ASCVD (secondary prevention)
• Patients with LDL-cholesterol levels ≥190 mg/dL
• Patients aged 40 to 75 years with diabetes mellitus
• Patients aged 40 to 75 years without diabetes mellitus who have LDL-cholesterol levels between 70 mg/dL and 189 mg/dL with an estimated 10-year risk for ASCVD of ≥7.5%

This patient fits into the fourth group and is therefore a candidate for statin therapy. Because his estimated 10-year risk of ASCVD is 9.0% (based on the ACC/AHA risk calculator), a moderate-intensity statin such as 40 mg of simvastatin is a reasonable choice; the 10-mg dose is considered low intensity.

Although family history is not included in the ACC/AHA risk calculator, this patient’s strong family history of early myocardial infarction adds weight to the decision to prescribe a statin. The most recent (2018) ACC/AHA cholesterol-lowering guidelines recommend using ASCVD risk enhancers, such as family history of premature ASCVD, chronic kidney disease, and South Asian ethnicity, to permit further risk stratification. We acknowledge, however, that some people have challenged the ACC/AHA guideline and risk calculator, arguing that they result in excessive treatment with statins for primary prevention of ASCVD in some nondiabetic patients.

In addition, the latest (2022) guidelines from the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force provide a grade C recommendation for prescribing statin therapy for primary prevention of CVD in individuals aged 40 to 75 years who have at least one CVD risk factor (e.g., dyslipidemia, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, smoking) plus an estimated 10-year ASCVD risk of 7.5% to 10%. The recommendation is upgraded to grade B if the estimated 10-year ASCVD risk is >10%.

Key learning point: According to current guidelines from the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association (ACC/AHA), patients without diabetes mellitus or clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) who have LDL-cholesterol levels between 70 and 189 mg/dL should be offered statin therapy if their estimated 10-year risk of ASCVD is ≥7.5%.

D) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient does not have diabetes mellitus, known cardiovascular disease, or a 10-year risk of ASCVD ≥10%, current guidelines would recommend initiation of pharmacologic therapy for hypertension only if his blood pressure exceeded 140/90 mm Hg. Given his current blood pressure, it would be reasonable to recommend continued lifestyle changes to help reduce the blood pressure, but lisinopril is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has a mild-to-moderate elevation of his triglyceride level; fibrate drugs (e.g., gemfibrozil, fenofibrate) can lower triglyceride levels to a greater degree than statins. However, statin therapy constitutes first-line lipid-lowering therapy in primary prevention of ASCVD. Fibrate therapy (primarily to reduce risk of pancreatitis) would be appropriate if the patient’s elevation in triglycerides was severe (e.g., >500 mg/dL).

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman returns to discuss the results of her recent lipid panel. She had a transient ischemic attack 2 years ago, and her only medications are aspirin, vitamin D, and calcium supplements. She does not smoke and has no history of angina or heart disease. She has a sister with hypothyroidism and a brother who was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes at age 65.
The patient’s blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg, her heart rate is 76 beats per minute, and her BMI is 22.7.
Laboratory testing yields a glycated hemoglobin value of 5.6% (reference range, 4.3–5.6) and the following lipid results:



Patient value


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
233


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
156


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
62


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
75


Which one of the following statin treatment recommendations is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Start rosuvastatin 10 mg once daily and ezetimibe 10 mg once daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Current (2018) cholesterol treatment guidelines from the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA) call for initiation or continuation of high-intensity statin therapy as first-line therapy in women and men ≤75 years of age who have clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD). This patient falls into this group because of her history of a transient ischemic attack. High-intensity statin therapy (such as atorvastatin 40–80 mg daily or rosuvastatin 20–40 mg daily) lowers LDL-cholesterol levels by ≥50% and reduces ASCVD risk more than moderate-intensity statin therapy with atorvastatin 10 mg, pravastatin 40 mg, simvastatin 20 to 40 mg, or rosuvastatin 10 mg daily.

B) INCORRECT:

Current (2018) cholesterol treatment guidelines from the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA) call for initiation or continuation of high-intensity statin therapy as first-line therapy in women and men ≤75 years of age who have clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD). This patient falls into this group because of her history of a transient ischemic attack. High-intensity statin therapy (such as atorvastatin 40–80 mg daily or rosuvastatin 20–40 mg daily) lowers LDL-cholesterol levels by ≥50% and reduces ASCVD risk more than moderate-intensity statin therapy with atorvastatin 10 mg, pravastatin 40 mg, simvastatin 20 to 40 mg, or rosuvastatin 10 mg daily.

C) CORRECT:

Current (2018) cholesterol treatment guidelines from the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA) call for initiation or continuation of high-intensity statin therapy as first-line therapy in women and men ≤75 years of age who have clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD). This patient falls into this group because of her history of a transient ischemic attack. High-intensity statin therapy (such as atorvastatin 40–80 mg daily or rosuvastatin 20–40 mg daily) lowers LDL-cholesterol levels by ≥50% and reduces ASCVD risk more than moderate-intensity statin therapy with atorvastatin 10 mg, pravastatin 40 mg, simvastatin 20 to 40 mg, or rosuvastatin 10 mg daily.

Key learning point: Statin therapy for a patient with a history of transient ischemic attack should be administered at doses that are considered to be high intensity.

D) INCORRECT:

According to the current ACC/AHA cholesterol guidelines, ezetimibe can reasonably be added to the regimens of patients at high risk who are already on maximally tolerated statins with LDL-cholesterol levels ≥70 mg/dL. The addition of ezetimibe to a statin can help lower LDL-cholesterol by an additional 13% to 20%. This patient is not on maximally tolerated statin therapy yet, so the addition of ezetimibe would not be indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Although simvastatin 80 mg daily was investigated in clinical trials, subsequent data showed an unacceptably high rate of myopathy with this dose. Therefore, no patients should be started on an 80-mg dose of simvastatin. Patients who have been taking this dose for a long time and are tolerating it may reasonably continue it, but clinicians should consider switching them to a different and more potent statin.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old woman with stage 3 chronic kidney disease secondary to polycystic kidney disease has a blood pressure of 118/78 mm Hg. Her kidneys are enlarged on palpation, but her physical examination is otherwise unremarkable, and she has no symptoms. She takes lisinopril 10 mg once daily. She quit smoking several months ago. Several members of her family have a history of coronary artery disease.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Serum creatinine (mg/dL)
2.5
0.6–1.1


Estimated glomerular filtration rate(mL/min/1.73 m2)
33
≥60


Urinary protein (mg/24 hr)
110

135
<130


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
55
≥46


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
220
125–200


The addition of which one of the following types of medication is most likely to reduce this patient’s risk for a major cardiovascular event?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient’s blood pressure is normal on treatment with an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor (a favored drug in patients with polycystic kidney disease). There is no evidence that adding an angiotensin-receptor blocker, beta-blocker, or loop diuretic would be cardioprotective in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

The benefit of lipid-lowering agents in preventing major adverse cardiovascular events in patients with dyslipidemia is well established in the general population. The latest (2018) guidelines from the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and American Heart Association (AHA) suggest that clinicians calculate a risk score for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) to help guide decision-making in the management of blood cholesterol. Statin therapy is clearly indicated for patients with significant hyperlipidemia, for secondary prevention, and for those with a risk score >10%.

This patient’s 10-year risk of heart disease or stroke is 5.5% using the AHA/ACC calculator, but this calculator does not take into account the patient’s additional risk factors, including her family history and her chronic kidney disease (CKD). CKD is considered a risk enhancer and should prompt discussions regarding use of statins, even if the risk score is below 10%, as is the case for this patient. Indeed, patients with CKD have a higher risk for cardiovascular disease than people in the general population because they have both traditional risk factors (such as hypertension) and nontraditional risk factors (such as alterations in mineral metabolism). For these patients, an ASCVD risk score of >5% should prompt a conversation about statins, and a risk score of >7.5% should prompt consideration of therapy. Patients who are taking a statin when they start dialysis may reasonably continue the medication, but for patients who are already on dialysis, there appears to be no benefit to starting a statin.

A Cochrane systematic review and meta-analysis (covering 50 studies with 45,000 patients) demonstrated that statins reduced the incidence of cardiovascular events and mortality by about 20% in patients with CKD who were not on dialysis. Most of these data were from subgroups of CKD patients within larger statin trials. In addition, the largest placebo-controlled trial devoted specifically to patients with CKD (the Study of Heart and Renal Protection [SHARP]) showed a significant benefit from simvastatin plus ezetimibe during 5 years of treatment. At enrollment, the 6200 SHARP participants who were not on dialysis had a mean estimated glomerular filtration rate of 27 mL/min/1.73 m2 and a mean LDL-cholesterol level of 112 mg/dL. Given the results of both the meta-analysis and the SHARP trial, it is reasonable to begin statin therapy in this patient.

Key learning point: The type of medication most likely to reduce the incidence of major cardiovascular events in non-dialysis-dependent, normotensive patients with chronic kidney disease is a statin.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient’s blood pressure is normal on treatment with an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor (a favored drug in patients with polycystic kidney disease). There is no evidence that adding an angiotensin-receptor blocker, beta-blocker, or loop diuretic would be cardioprotective in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient’s blood pressure is normal on treatment with an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor (a favored drug in patients with polycystic kidney disease). There is no evidence that adding an angiotensin-receptor blocker, beta-blocker, or loop diuretic would be cardioprotective in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

According to a recent meta-analysis, the benefits of antiplatelet therapy in patients with chronic kidney disease are unclear and potentially outweighed by the increased risk for bleeding.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman with a history of obesity and impaired fasting glucose presents for a regularly scheduled visit. She has no specific concerns but is newly motivated to improve her health because her first grandchild was recently born, and she would like to see him grow up.
She has no personal or family history of cardiovascular disease or cancer. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes per day since age 22. She walks for 30 minutes three times per week but does not engage in any other formal exercise.
Her blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg, her heart rate is 62 beats per minute, her BMI is 33, and her waist circumference is 85 cm. Her physical examination is unremarkable.
Her laboratory results are as follows:

Her estimated 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is 5.8%.
In addition to smoking-cessation counseling, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate niacin 250 mg once daily; increase the dose as tolerated
Initiate metformin 500 mg once daily; increase the dose as tolerated

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although niacin does raise HDL-cholesterol levels, its use alone has not been shown to improve cardiovascular outcomes.

B) CORRECT:

This patient is currently at relatively low cardiovascular risk and is motivated to reduce her risk further. Smoking cessation will have the greatest effect. Intensive lifestyle modification, rather than medication, is the best initial option for managing her hyperlipidemia and prediabetes. Lifestyle interventions should include dietary changes to promote weight loss and an increase in aerobic exercise. Evidence has shown that for every 5 to 8 kilograms of weight lost, there is a roughly 5-mg/dL reduction in LDL cholesterol and a 2- to 3-mg/dL increase in HDL cholesterol.

In patients such as this one who are at borderline risk (10-year ASCVD risk of 5%–7.5%), lifestyle modification is the foundation of risk reduction. However, if risk-enhancing factors (listed below) are present in such patients, moderate-intensity statin therapy may be justified after risk discussion. This patient does not have any such factors.

• Persistently elevated LDL cholesterol ≥160 mg/dL
• Family history of premature ASCVD
• Chronic kidney disease
• Metabolic syndrome
• History of preeclampsia or premature menopause
• Inflammatory diseases (especially rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, HIV infection
• South Asian ancestry
• Persistently elevated triglycerides ≥175 mg/dL
• High-sensitivity C-reactive protein ≥2.0 mmol/liter
• Lipoprotein(a) ≥50 mg/dL
• Apolipoprotein B ≥130 mg/dL
• Ankle-brachial index <0.9

Key learning point: Initial management of hyperlipidemia and prediabetes in a patient with borderline risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease should focus on therapeutic intensive lifestyle changes.

C) INCORRECT:

Statin therapy is not indicated in this patient, according to joint guidelines from the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association. In asymptomatic adults aged 40 to 75 without established cardiovascular disease or diabetes, statin therapy is strongly recommended only if the LDL cholesterol level exceeds 190 mg/dL or the 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) exceeds 7.5%.

D) INCORRECT:

Statin therapy is not indicated in this patient, according to joint guidelines from the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association. In asymptomatic adults aged 40 to 75 without established cardiovascular disease or diabetes, statin therapy is strongly recommended only if the LDL cholesterol level exceeds 190 mg/dL or the 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) exceeds 7.5%.

E) INCORRECT:

In this patient with impaired fasting glucose and a glycated hemoglobin level in the prediabetic range, metformin could be initiated with the goal of delaying progression to overt diabetes. However, in a large randomized trial (the Diabetes Prevention Trial), an intensive lifestyle intervention was more effective than metformin for this purpose; in addition, there is no strong evidence that metformin therapy, initiated in patients with prediabetes, reduces the incidence of long-term diabetes complications.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to establish care. He reports that he exercises for 30 minutes four times per week on his spin bicycle without any cardiac symptoms. He previously smoked a half-pack of cigarettes daily but quit 30 years ago. He consumes four alcoholic drinks per week. His father had a myocardial infarction at 60 years of age, and the patient is very motivated to reduce his own risk of cardiovascular events. He has switched from red meats to lean meats and is adding more vegetables and whole grains to his diet. His current medications are lisinopril 10 mg daily and pravastatin 20 mg daily.
His heart rate is 76 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 128/79 mm Hg, and he has a BMI of 26. His physical examination is unremarkable.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
200
125–200


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
174
<150


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
42
≥40


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
123
<130


Glycated hemoglobin (%)
5.6
3.8–5.6


The patient’s estimated 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is 11.4%.
Which one of the following medication changes would be most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Switch the statin to atorvastatin 20 mg daily
Increase the dose of lisinopril to 20 mg daily
Start icosapent ethyl 2 g twice daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Initiation of low-dose aspirin is not indicated in this case. The routine use of aspirin for primary prevention of cardiovascular disease is no longer encouraged. In 2018, three pivotal randomized trials (ASCEND, ARRIVE, and ASPREE) showed that routine aspirin usein this setting significantly increased the risk of adverse bleeding events with variable benefits among older adults with and without diabetes mellitus. Current ACC/AHA guidelines state that aspirin should not be used for primary prevention of ASCVD among adults >70 years of age — or among adults of any age who are at increased risk for bleeding. The guidelines do, however, state that low-dose aspirin can be considered for primary prevention among select adults aged 40 to 70 who are at increased ASCVD risk but not at increased bleeding risk, using an individualized approach. A 10-year ASCVD risk score ≥20%, the presence of multiple risk enhancers, or a coronary artery calcium score >100 may factor into this decision. Risk enhancers include:

• Family history of premature ASCVD in a first-degree relative (men, age <55; women, <65)
• Chronic kidney disease
• Metabolic syndrome
• Chronic inflammatory conditions
• South Asian ancestry
• Persistent LDL-cholesterol levels ≥160 mg/dL
• Persistent triglyceride levels ≥175 mg/dL
• High-sensitivity C-reactive protein levels ≥2 mg/dL
• Lipoprotein (a) levels ≥50 mg/dL

In this case, the patient has an intermediate ASCVD risk score of <20%, no family history of premature ASCVD, and no other risk-enhancing factors; thus, aspirin for primary prevention is not indicated.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s estimated 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) falls between 7.5% and 20%, placing him in the intermediate risk category for ASCVD. Current (2019) guidelines from the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and American Heart Association (AHA) recommend initiating a moderate-intensity statin in intermediate-risk patients after a thorough discussion of risks and benefits, with a goal of reducing LDL-cholesterol levels by 30% to 49%. Given that this patient is currently taking only a low-intensity statin, switching to at least a moderate-intensity statin would be the most appropriate recommendation. He already has optimal lifestyle behaviors.

Key learning point: In a patient at intermediate risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease who does not have multiple risk-enhancing factors and is already following optimal lifestyle recommendations, the most appropriate intervention for primary prevention is a moderate-intensity statin.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient’s blood pressure goal would be no lower than <130/80 mm Hg. Given that his blood pressure is already at goal, increasing the dose of lisinopril is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Icosapent ethyl is indicated as an adjunct to maximally tolerated statin therapy to reduce ASCVD risk in patients with triglyceride levels ≥150 mg/dL who are at high cardiovascular risk due to established ASCVD or to type 2 diabetes with at least one additional ASCVD risk factor. This patient does not meet the criteria for the addition of icosapent ethyl.

E) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor that is used as an adjunct to maximally tolerated statin therapy to achieve LDL-cholesterol goals for primary or secondary prevention of ASCVD. This patient is not on a maximally tolerated statin dose and would not warrant initiation of ezetimibe.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes presents for follow-up. In the 6 months since her last visit, she has lost 4.5 kg of body weight through diet and exercise. Medications are metformin, lisinopril, and multivitamin. Her blood pressure is 123/74 mm Hg, and her BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination is unremarkable. A fasting lipid panel reveals the following results:


Total cholesterol
189 mg/dL


LDL cholesterol
95 mg/dL


HDL cholesterol
43 mg/dL


Triglycerides
255 mg/dL


Which one of the following treatments is recommended to minimize this patient’s long-term cardiovascular risk?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Icosapent ethyl effectively reduces triglyceride concentrations, especially in individuals with severe hypertriglyceridemia (>500 mg/dL). Studies have shown cardiovascular benefit when icosapent ethyl is added to a statin in patients with hypertriglyceridemia who are at high cardiovascular risk (due to established ASCVD or to type 2 diabetes with at least one additional ASCVD risk factor). Current guidelines therefore suggest considering icosapent ethyl as an addition to a statin in this patient population. However, starting a statin should take precedence.

B) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe is a second-line lipid-lowering agent that can be used for additional atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk reduction in patients who do not achieve target LDL reduction with the maximally tolerated dose of first-line therapy. This patient's LDL cholesterol is within the reference range.

C) INCORRECT:

Nicotinic acid and fibrates have not been consistently shown to lower cardiovascular risk and are generally reserved for patients with a severely elevated triglyceride level or a very low HDL-cholesterol level.

D) INCORRECT:

Nicotinic acid and fibrates have not been consistently shown to lower cardiovascular risk and are generally reserved for patients with a severely elevated triglyceride level or a very low HDL-cholesterol level.

E) CORRECT:

Current cholesterol treatment guidelines from the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA) outline four “statin benefit” groups for whom atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk reduction clearly outweighs the risk for adverse events. One of those groups is patients aged 40 to 75 years with diabetes mellitus, regardless of their estimated risk for ASCVD. These patients should receive at least moderate-intensity statin therapy. If they have multiple ASCVD risk factors, they should receive a high-intensity statin, with the goal of reducing LDL-cholesterol levels by ≥50% to a target LDL-cholesterol level of <70 mg/dL. This patient should receive a moderate-intensity statin.

Key learning point: Regardless of estimated risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, primary prevention in patients aged 40 to 75 years with type 2 diabetes should include at least moderate-intensity statin therapy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He recently moved to the area. He feels well. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus, and his paternal uncle had prostate cancer at the age of 73 years. The patient does not smoke cigarettes. He drinks three glasses of wine weekly. He works as a scriptwriter for a film production company and runs marathons to raise money for charity organizations in his free time. He has been monogamous with his wife for 15 years. He is 185 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Early detection and treatment of hyperlipidemia is crucial to prevent ASCVD events like stroke or myocardial infarction. The guidelines for hyperlipidemia screening differ slightly among various expert groups. The current consensus is to screen all individuals aged 20–75 years using a fasting or nonfasting serum lipid profile test every 4–6 years in patients without additional ASCVD risk factors and at more frequent intervals in those with additional ASCVD risk factors.

See “Screening recommendations for men by age” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia and gonorrhea are the most common causes of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Although PID is most often asymptomatic, it can result in severe complications, including infertility and ectopic pregnancy. Therefore, both the USPSTF and CDC recommend annual screening with a nucleic acid amplification test for chlamydia and gonorrhea in sexually active women < 25 years and women ≥ 25 years with certain risk factors (e.g., new or multiple sex partners, a sex partner with an STI). The CDC also recommends annual screening for both sexually active HIV-positive men and men who have sex with men because of the higher incidence of gonorrhea and chlamydia infections in these populations. Routine chlamydia and gonorrhea screening is not currently recommended for sexually active, HIV-negative men in monogamous, heterosexual relationships, such as this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The AHA and other expert groups do recommend screening for a certain disease in this patient's age group.

D) INCORRECT:

The guidelines for prostate cancer screening differ slightly among various expert groups but the USPSTF recommends screening men aged 55–69 years with a life expectancy of at least 10 years after informing the patient of the benefits as well as risks of prostate cancer screening (e.g., relatively high false-positive rate, additional unnecessary procedures), i.e., by employing a shared decision-making strategy. Prostate cancer screening is most commonly performed using a serum prostate-specific antigen test every 2 years. Screening can be initiated earlier at 40 years for patients with a first-degree relative who developed early-onset prostate cancer (i.e., before 65 years). This 42-year-old patient with a second-degree relative who developed prostate cancer at the age of 73 years does not require prostate cancer screening at this visit.

E) INCORRECT:

There is insufficient evidence to recommend routine screening for osteoporosis in men, but screening can be considered in men with strong risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., long-term corticosteroid use; androgen deprivation therapy for prostate cancer) and in men ≥ 70 years of age. In this 42-year old man without such risk factors, screening for osteoporosis is not recommended.
questions.hint: Screening for this disorder is recommended by the American Heart Association and various other expert groups for the primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular diseases (ASCVD).

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman with a history of obesity and impaired fasting glucose comes to the office for a regularly scheduled visit. She wants to improve her health. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes per day since age 22. She walks for 30 minutes three times per week. Results of laboratory studies are shown:


Serum



 Total cholesterol
198 mg/dL


 HDL cholesterol
36 mg/dL


 LDL cholesterol
140 mg/dL


 Triglycerides
111 mg/dL


 Glucose
102 mg/dL


Blood



 Hemoglobin A1C

5.9%


Her estimated 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is 5.8%. In addition to smoking-cessation counseling, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although niacin does raise HDL-cholesterol levels, its use alone has not been shown to improve cardiovascular outcomes.

B) CORRECT:

This patient is currently at relatively low cardiovascular risk and is motivated to reduce her risk further. Smoking cessation will have the greatest effect. Intensive lifestyle modification, rather than medication, is the best initial option for managing her hyperlipidemia and prediabetes. Lifestyle interventions should include dietary changes to promote weight loss and an increase in aerobic exercise. Evidence has shown that for every 5 to 8 kilograms of weight lost, there is a roughly 5-mg/dL reduction in LDL cholesterol and a 2- to 3-mg/dL increase in HDL cholesterol.

In patients such as this one who are at borderline risk (10-year ASCVD risk of 5%–7.5%), lifestyle modification is the foundation of risk reduction. However, if risk-enhancing factors (listed below) are present in such patients, moderate-intensity statin therapy may be justified after risk discussion. This patient does not have any such factors.

• Persistently elevated LDL cholesterol ≥160 mg/dL
• Family history of premature ASCVD
• Chronic kidney disease
• Metabolic syndrome
• History of preeclampsia or premature menopause
• Inflammatory diseases (especially rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, HIV infection
• South Asian ancestry
• Persistently elevated triglycerides ≥175 mg/dL
• High-sensitivity C-reactive protein ≥2.0 mmol/liter
• Lipoprotein(a) ≥50 mg/dL
• Apolipoprotein B ≥130 mg/dL
• Ankle-brachial index <0.9

Key learning point: Initial management of hyperlipidemia and prediabetes in a patient with borderline risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease should focus on therapeutic intensive lifestyle changes.

C) INCORRECT:

Statin therapy is not indicated in this patient, according to joint guidelines from the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association. In asymptomatic adults aged 40 to 75 without established cardiovascular disease or diabetes, statin therapy is strongly recommended only if the LDL cholesterol level exceeds 190 mg/dL or the 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) exceeds 7.5%.

D) INCORRECT:

Statin therapy is not indicated in this patient, according to joint guidelines from the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association. In asymptomatic adults aged 40 to 75 without established cardiovascular disease or diabetes, statin therapy is strongly recommended only if the LDL cholesterol level exceeds 190 mg/dL or the 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) exceeds 7.5%.

E) INCORRECT:

In this patient with impaired fasting glucose and a glycated hemoglobin level in the prediabetic range, metformin could be initiated with the goal of delaying progression to overt diabetes. However, in a large randomized trial (the Diabetes Prevention Trial), an intensive lifestyle intervention was more effective than metformin for this purpose; in addition, there is no strong evidence that metformin therapy, initiated in patients with prediabetes, reduces the incidence of long-term diabetes complications.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of crushing substernal chest pain at rest for the past 2 hours. She is diaphoretic. Pulse is 110/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 115/65 mm Hg. Electrocardiography shows ST elevation in I, aVL, and V2–V4. Coronary angiography shows an 80% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery. Which of the following is the most likely initial step in the pathogenesis of this patient's coronary condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intimal foam cell accumulation is a consequence of macrophages infiltrating the intima and ingesting cholesterol from oxidized LDL. These foam cells accumulate and form fatty streaks. However, intimal foam cell accumulation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Platelet activation releases a variety of inflammatory mediators and thereby recruits inflammatory cells towards the site of the atherosclerotic lesion. However, platelets are only activated after adhesion to the endothelium of affected vessels. Therefore, platelet activation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Intimal monocyte infiltration is one of the first steps in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis. After adhesion to the endothelium, the monocytes emigrate through the endothelium into the intima. As the endothelium is physiologically impermeable to monocytes, monocyte infiltration is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

D) CORRECT:

The development of atherosclerosis begins with an external factor (e.g., hypertension, smoking, advanced glycation end-products) damaging the endothelium, which increases adhesiveness and leads to local inflammation and invasion of smooth muscle cells into the tunica intima. Inflammatory cytokines attract macrophages, which then form foam cells by taking up cholesterol from oxidized low-density lipids. These foam cells accumulate to form fatty streaks (early atherosclerotic lesions). Finally, collagen production by lipid-laden macrophages and SMCs form these fatty streaks into a fibrous plaque.

E) INCORRECT:

Fibrous plaque formation is mediated by macrophages, lymphocytes, and smooth muscle cells. Together with deposited extracellular matrix (e.g., collagen), these cell types form the fibrous plaque in atherosclerosis. However, fibrous plaque formation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (acute, crushing substernal chest pain, diaphoresis) and ECG changes indicate a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome (ACS). The angiography showing a stenosis of the left anterior descending artery confirms the diagnosis. ACS is caused primarily by atherosclerosis.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man with a history of obesity and hypertension presents for routine care. His hypertension is currently being treated with hydrochlorothiazide. He leads a sedentary lifestyle, consumes a diet high in saturated fats, and has one glass of wine with dinner 5 to 6 nights per week. His height is 165 cm, his weight is 94 kg, his BMI is 34.5, and his waist circumference is 114 cm. He has mild acanthosis nigricans on his neck. The remainder of his physical examination is normal. Results of laboratory studies are shown:


Cholesterol



 Total
182 mg/dL


 LDL
98 mg/dL


 HDL
24 mg/dL


Triglycerides
300 mg/dL


Hemoglobin A1C
5.9%


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient’s cholesterol levels?

choices.text: Estimate the patient's 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Current cholesterol-lowering guidelines recommend initiating pharmacologic therapy in adults with clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), diabetes mellitus, an LDL-cholesterol level ≥190 mg/dL, or a ≥7.5% estimated 10-year ASCVD risk. Although this patient has an elevated triglyceride level and low HDL-cholesterol concentration, his glycated hemoglobin level is in the prediabetic rather than the diabetic range, and his estimated 10-year ASCVD risk is only 6.5%, so pharmacologic therapy is not mandatory at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Current cholesterol-lowering guidelines recommend initiating statin therapy in adults with clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), diabetes mellitus, an LDL-cholesterol level ≥190 mg/dL, or a ≥7.5% estimated 10-year ASCVD risk. Although this patient has an elevated triglyceride level and low HDL-cholesterol concentration, his glycated hemoglobin level is in the prediabetic rather than the diabetic range, and his estimated 10-year ASCVD risk is only 6.5%, so pharmacologic therapy is not mandatory at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Current cholesterol-lowering guidelines recommend initiating pharmacologic therapy in adults with clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), diabetes mellitus, an LDL-cholesterol level ≥190 mg/dL, or a ≥7.5% estimated 10-year ASCVD risk. Although this patient has an elevated triglyceride level and low HDL-cholesterol concentration, his glycated hemoglobin level is in the prediabetic rather than the diabetic range, and his estimated 10-year ASCVD risk is only 6.5%, so pharmacologic therapy is not mandatory at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Although observational studies suggest that high intake of dietary fish oil is associated with reduced cardiovascular risk, randomized trials of omega-3 fatty acid supplementation in patients with known coronary disease have yielded mixed results for secondary prevention. The REDUCE-IT trial showed that, compared with placebo, regular use of icosapent ethyl was associated with improved cardiovascular outcomes among patients with high triglyceride levels who had known cardiovascular disease or relevant risk factors and were already taking statin therapy. Our patient, however, does not fit this category.

E) CORRECT:

Current cholesterol-lowering guidelines recommend initiating statin therapy in adults with clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), diabetes mellitus, an LDL-cholesterol level ≥190 mg/dL, or a ≥7.5% estimated 10-year ASCVD risk. Although this patient has an elevated triglyceride level and low HDL-cholesterol concentration, his glycated hemoglobin level is in the prediabetic rather than the diabetic range, and his estimated 10-year ASCVD risk is only 6.5%, so pharmacologic therapy is not mandatory at this time.

In patients with (or at high risk for) ASCVD, statins appear to lower risk of cardiovascular death more effectively than other lipid-lowering agents such as fibrates (e.g., gemfibrozil or fenofibrate) or niacin. Thus, statins are the treatment of choice for patients with high 10-year ASCVD risk and moderately elevated triglyceride levels. However, in patients with very high triglyceride levels (>500–1000 mg/dL), drugs that target triglycerides more directly (e.g., fibrates) are recommended to prevent pancreatitis. When patients have both a high 10-year ASCVD risk and severely elevated triglyceride levels (e.g., >1000 mg/dL), dual therapy with a statin plus fibrate or niacin may be considered, but risk for adverse effects (including myopathy) rises.

Key learning point: The best way to manage a patient with an elevated triglyceride level and a low HDL-cholesterol level is to base therapy on the patient's estimated 10-year risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man presents for a routine follow-up. Nine months ago, he had an ST-elevation myocardial infarction treated with percutaneous coronary intervention. He has adhered to lifestyle modifications, including tobacco cessation and daily exercise. His current medications are aspirin, a moderate-intensity statin, and lisinopril. He reports occasional muscle discomfort that does not limit physical activity. Physical examination is normal (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Total cholesterol
4.8 mmol/L
< 5.1 mmol/L


Cholesterol (LDL)
2.4 mmol/L
< 3.36 mmol/L


Cholesterol (HDL)
1.0 mmol/L
> 1.03 mmol/L


Triglycerides
1.5 mmol/L
< 2.16 mmol/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management to reduce his cardiovascular risk?

choices.text: Increase statin therapy to a high-intensity regimen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

For patients with coronary artery disease, especially post-ST-elevation myocardial infarction, guidelines recommend high-intensity statin therapy to achieve greater LDL reduction. Although the patient's LDL levels are within general population limits, secondary prevention targets are lower. Mild myalgias do not contraindicate intensifying therapy, and high-intensity regimens offer substantial benefits in post-myocardial infarction patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Niacin raises high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol and lowers triglycerides, but it does not reduce cardiovascular events when added to statin therapy. The patient's LDL is well controlled, and while HDL is slightly low, niacin's adverse effects, such as flushing and potential glycemic control alterations, outweigh its benefits in this context.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, such as those with a history of ST-elevation myocardial infarction, benefit from aggressive low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol lowering. High-intensity statins aim for at least a 50% reduction in LDL cholesterol and provide additional benefits, including plaque stabilization and reduced systemic inflammation. These effects decrease the risk of recurrent cardiovascular events. Although the patient's LDL levels are within target ranges for the general population, secondary prevention guidelines recommend high-intensity statin therapy for post-acute coronary syndrome patients. Mild muscle discomfort is a known side effect, but the benefits of high-intensity statins outweigh this risk in high-risk individuals.

Key learning point: In patients with a history of myocardial infarction, high-intensity statin therapy is recommended for secondary prevention to achieve significant LDL cholesterol reduction and reduce the risk of future cardiovascular events.

D) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe, which blocks intestinal cholesterol absorption, is used when LDL cholesterol remains above target despite maximal tolerated statin therapy. This patient is on moderate-intensity statin therapy with mild myalgias, suggesting that his statin regimen can be intensified rather than supplemented. Ezetimibe is typically reserved for those on maximal statin therapy or who are statin-intolerant.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents for a routine follow-up. He has a history of myocardial infarction and stable coronary artery disease. He reports walking daily with no chest discomfort and has been on a moderate-intensity statin for the past six months without any intolerable side effects (see lab results).


Heart rate
74/min


Blood pressure
130/80 mm Hg




Test
Result
Normal Values



Total cholesterol
5.5 mmol/L
< 5.1 mmol/L


Cholesterol (LDL)
3.2 mmol/L
< 3.36 mmol/L


Cholesterol (HDL)
1.0 mmol/L
> 1.03 mmol/L


Triglycerides
1.5 mmol/L
< 2.16 mmol/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to reduce this patient’s risk of future cardiovascular events?

choices.text: Repeat lipid profile in three months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While periodic lipid monitoring is important, this patient with coronary artery disease and a history of myocardial infarction requires more immediate intervention. His lipid levels are suboptimal for secondary prevention, and delaying treatment intensification could increase cardiovascular risk. Guidelines recommend intensifying lipid-lowering strategies rather than waiting.

B) INCORRECT:

Bile acid sequestrants modestly reduce LDL cholesterol by increasing hepatic conversion of cholesterol to bile acids. They are considered when statins are not tolerated or additional LDL lowering is needed. This patient tolerates statins well, and his LDL level is acceptable. Statins are preferred for their robust cardiovascular risk reduction.

C) CORRECT:

In patients with established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, aggressive low-density lipoprotein (LDL) reduction is crucial for secondary prevention. High-intensity statin therapy, such as atorvastatin 40-80 mg or rosuvastatin 20-40 mg, typically lowers LDL cholesterol by 50% or more. This reduction is associated with decreased cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. High-intensity statins also improve endothelial function and stabilize plaques, reducing the risk of recurrent cardiovascular events. Current guidelines recommend maximizing statin therapy for secondary prevention in patients with coronary artery disease.

Key learning point: In patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, high-intensity statin therapy is recommended for secondary prevention to reduce the risk of future cardiovascular events.

D) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe lowers LDL cholesterol and is used when statin therapy alone is insufficient or not tolerated. This patient is on a moderate-intensity statin without intolerable side effects, and his LDL level does not necessitate immediate adjunct therapy. Optimizing statin dosing is preferred before adding ezetimibe.

questions.text: An overweight 47-year-old man with borderline hypertension and elevated LDL works at a desk job and avoids physical activity. Which measure best addresses his major modifiable risk factor for reducing cardiovascular risk?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-intensity statin therapy lowers LDL cholesterol and is used in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease or markedly elevated LDL levels. The patient's primary risk factor is a sedentary lifestyle and overweight status, which contribute to multiple cardiovascular risks. Lifestyle modifications address these underlying behavioral risk factors more comprehensively.

B) INCORRECT:

Daily low-dose aspirin therapy is used for patients with established cardiovascular disease or high risk, where benefits outweigh bleeding risks. It does not address the patient's sedentary lifestyle or overweight status, which are primary risk factors. Aspirin reduces thrombus formation but does not modify lifestyle factors driving cardiovascular risk.

C) INCORRECT:

Strict sodium restriction lowers blood pressure by reducing extracellular fluid volume but does not target the patient's primary risk factor: sedentary lifestyle and overweight status. Sodium reduction has a modest impact on blood pressure and does not improve dyslipidemia or promote weight loss.

D) CORRECT:

Regular moderate-intensity exercise addresses the patient's sedentary lifestyle, a major modifiable cardiovascular risk factor. Aerobic activity improves endothelial function, increases high-density lipoprotein (HDL) levels, and reduces low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol. Exercise also helps manage blood pressure and promotes weight loss, beneficial for borderline hypertension and overweight status. By enhancing insulin sensitivity and reducing systemic inflammation, exercise mitigates cardiovascular risk through multidimensional metabolic health improvements.

Key learning point: A sedentary lifestyle is a significant risk factor for cardiovascular disease due to its association with obesity, hypertension, and dyslipidemia.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes comes to your clinic for follow-up. Since her last visit 6 months ago, she has lost 4.5 kg through diet and exercise. Her medications include metformin, lisinopril, and a multivitamin. Her blood pressure is 123/74 mm Hg, and her BMI is 22. Physical examination is unremarkable. A fasting lipid panel shows the following results:


Cholesterol, total, blood
4.9 mmol/L (3.5–5.2)


Cholesterol, LDL, blood
2.5 mmol/L (see the LDL Analysis table below)


Cholesterol, HDL, blood
1.1 mmol/L (>1.3)


Triglycerides, blood
2.9 mmol/L (≤1.7)


LDL Analysis


Cardiovascular Disease Risk
When to Consider Initiating Treatment
Treatment Target



High and intermediate
LDL level of ≥ 3.5 mmol/L
LDL level of < 2.0 mmol/L or ≥50% reduction in pretherapy LDL level


Low
LDL level of > 5.0 mmol/L
≥50% reduction in pretherapy LDL level



Which one of the following treatments is recommended to minimize her long-term cardiovascular risk?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe is a second-line lipid-lowering agent that can be used for additional atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk reduction in patients who do not achieve target LDL reduction with the maximally tolerated dose of first-line therapy. This patient's LDL cholesterol is within the reference range.

B) INCORRECT:

Icosapent ethyl effectively reduces triglyceride concentrations, especially in individuals with severe hypertriglyceridemia (> 5.65 mmol/L). Studies have shown cardiovascular benefit when icosapent ethyl is added to a statin in patients with hypertriglyceridemia who are at high cardiovascular risk (due to established ASCVD or to type 2 diabetes with at least one additional ASCVD risk factor). Current guidelines therefore suggest considering icosapent ethyl as an addition to a statin in this patient population. However, starting a statin should take precedence.

C) CORRECT:

Current cholesterol treatment guidelines from the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA) outline four “statin benefit” groups for whom atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk reduction clearly outweighs the risk for adverse events. One of those groups is patients aged 40 to 75 years with diabetes mellitus, regardless of their estimated risk for ASCVD. These patients should receive at least moderate-intensity statin therapy. If they have multiple ASCVD risk factors, they should receive a high-intensity statin, with the goal of reducing LDL-cholesterol levels by ≥ 50% to a target LDL-cholesterol level of < 1.81 mmol/L. This patient should receive a moderate-intensity statin.

Key learning point: Regardless of estimated risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, primary prevention in patients aged 40 to 75 years with type 2 diabetes should include at least moderate-intensity statin therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Nicotinic acid and fibrates have not been consistently shown to lower cardiovascular risk and are generally reserved for patients with a severely elevated triglyceride level or a very low HDL-cholesterol level.

E) INCORRECT:

Nicotinic acid and fibrates have not been consistently shown to lower cardiovascular risk and are generally reserved for patients with a severely elevated triglyceride level or a very low HDL-cholesterol level.

questions.text: You are seeing a 61-year-old woman who is brought to the emergency department with crushing substernal chest pain at rest for the past 2 hours. She is diaphoretic. Her pulse is 110/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 115/65 mm Hg. Electrocardiography shows ST elevation in leads I, aVL, and V2–V4. Coronary angiography reveals an 80% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery. Which one of the following is the most likely initial step in the pathogenesis of her coronary condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibrous plaque formation is mediated by macrophages, lymphocytes, and smooth muscle cells. Together with deposited extracellular matrix (e.g., collagen), these cell types form the fibrous plaque in atherosclerosis. However, fibrous plaque formation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Intimal monocyte infiltration is one of the first steps in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis. After adhesion to the endothelium, the monocytes emigrate through the endothelium into the intima. As the endothelium is physiologically impermeable to monocytes, monocyte infiltration is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

C) CORRECT:

The development of atherosclerosis begins with an external factor (e.g., hypertension, smoking, advanced glycation end-products) damaging the endothelium, which increases adhesiveness and leads to local inflammation and invasion of smooth muscle cells into the tunica intima. Inflammatory cytokines attract macrophages, which then form foam cells by taking up cholesterol from oxidized low-density lipids. These foam cells accumulate to form fatty streaks (early atherosclerotic lesions). Finally, collagen production by lipid-laden macrophages and SMCs form these fatty streaks into a fibrous plaque.

Key learning point: The initial step in atherosclerosis pathogenesis is endothelial cell dysfunction caused by factors such as hypertension or smoking, leading to increased vascular permeability and inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

Intimal foam cell accumulation is a consequence of macrophages infiltrating the intima and ingesting cholesterol from oxidized LDL. These foam cells accumulate and form fatty streaks. However, intimal foam cell accumulation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Platelet activation releases a variety of inflammatory mediators and thereby recruits inflammatory cells towards the site of the atherosclerotic lesion. However, platelets are only activated after adhesion to the endothelium of affected vessels. Therefore, platelet activation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (acute, crushing substernal chest pain, diaphoresis) and ECG changes indicate a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome (ACS). The angiography showing a stenosis of the left anterior descending artery confirms the diagnosis. ACS is caused primarily by atherosclerosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents for a routine follow-up. He had a myocardial infarction two years ago. His medical history is also significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He reports good adherence to his medications, which include atorvastatin 80 mg daily, lisinopril, metoprolol, and low-dose aspirin. He has no new complaints. His blood pressure is 134/82 mm Hg. A recent lipid panel shows a total cholesterol of 175 mg/dL, LDL cholesterol of 95 mg/dL, HDL cholesterol of 40 mg/dL, and triglycerides of 130 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate modification to this patient's medication regimen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fenofibrate is primarily used to lower triglycerides. Although hypertriglyceridemia can occur in patients with diabetes, this patient's triglyceride level of 130 mg/dL is within the normal range (< 150 mg/dL). The primary therapeutic target in this patient is LDL cholesterol reduction for secondary atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease prevention, and fibrates have a minimal effect on LDL levels.

B) INCORRECT:

Icosapent ethyl is indicated for cardiovascular risk reduction in patients with established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease or diabetes who have elevated triglycerides (≥ 150 mg/dL) despite statin therapy. Although this patient has atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease and diabetes, his triglyceride level is 130 mg/dL, which does not meet the criteria for initiating this medication. The primary goal is to lower his LDL cholesterol.

C) INCORRECT:

Niacin was historically used for lipid management. However, major clinical trials have shown that adding niacin to statin therapy does not provide additional cardiovascular benefit and increases the risk of adverse effects, such as flushing and hyperglycemia. Current guidelines no longer recommend niacin for secondary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.

D) CORRECT:

Ezetimibe inhibits intestinal cholesterol absorption, providing an additional 15–20% reduction in LDL when combined with a statin. Despite this patient being on a maximally tolerated high-intensity statin (atorvastatin 80 mg), his LDL is 95 mg/dL. When the LDL goal is not met with statin therapy alone, the first-line recommendation is to add a non-statin agent. Ezetimibe is the preferred initial add-on therapy. If the LDL goal is still not achieved, a proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 inhibitor would be the next consideration.
questions.hint: This patient has clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, placing him in the very high-risk category for secondary prevention. The goal LDL cholesterol for this population is < 70 mg/dL.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and decreased urine output for 2 weeks. He has not been to the physician for many years and takes no medications. Serum studies show a urea nitrogen concentration of 42 mg/dL and a creatinine concentration of 2.3 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows heavy proteinuria. A photomicrograph of a section of a kidney biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In diabetes mellitus, chronic hyperglycemia promotes the attachment of carbohydrates to proteins, a process known as nonenzymatic protein glycation (NEPG), which alters the structure and function of the glycated protein. NEPG of the glomerular basement membrane renders it permeable to plasma proteins, which accumulate within the walls of the glomerular arterioles, causing arteriolar thickening and narrowing. This protein accumulation appears as pink amorphous material within the vascular wall on H&E staining and is known as hyaline arteriolosclerosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Renal amyloidosis results from the deposition of β-sheet fibrils within the mesangial matrix and glomeruli of the kidney. Renal amyloidosis can present with proteinuria and renal failure, as seen in this patient. Although amyloid deposits resemble the pink hyaline material seen here, similar deposits would also be expected in the mesangium and interstitium of the kidney.
Image Description:

Microscopic image of kidney tissue (Congo red stain, approx. 300x)

Two glomeruli containing abnormal hyaline depositions (arrow) are seen in the center of the image.
The interstitial tissue exhibits identical depositions (arrowheads).

Hyaline depositions that stain with Congo red are suggestive of amyloidosis. A definitive diagnosis can only be made by subjecting the sample to polarizing light microscopy.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD) of the renal artery can manifest with renal failure. However, FMD typically affects medium to small-sized arteries, such as the renal artery, carotid artery, mesenteric arteries, as opposed to arterioles. H&E staining of a vessel affected by FMD would show collagen deposition in the tunica media or tunica intima.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with chronic essential hypertension can show hyaline arteriolosclerosis on renal biopsy, as seen in this patient. However, a renal biopsy in patients with long-term severe or malignant hypertension would predominantly show hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis, characterized by an onion-skin appearance of the arteriolar wall due to vascular smooth muscle proliferation, as well as fibrinoid necrosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney tissue sample (PAS stain, medium magnification)

Various elements of the renal tubular and vascular system are seen in different sections. An arteriole is visible on the left (arrow), showing a thick, laminated wall (onion-skin appearance) due to hyperplasia of the smooth muscle tissue (examples of nuclei indicated by yellow overlay) and reduplicated basement membrane material, which stains PAS-positive (magenta-colored laminae; examples indicated by arrowheads). The lumen is severely narrowed as a consequence of these vessel wall changes.

These are typical features of hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Dyslipidemia is a risk factor for atherosclerosis. An atheroma in the renal artery can cause renal artery stenosis, which can lead to renal failure. However, atherosclerosis affects medium-sized or large vessels (e.g., the aorta, coronary arteries, renal artery), as opposed to arterioles. H&E staining of an atherosclerotic vessel would show cholesterol plaques, foam cells, and smooth muscle proliferation.
questions.hint: The patient's symptoms and serum studies suggest renal failure. Renal biopsy shows a thickened, hyaline arterial wall consistent with hyaline arteriosclerosis.
